A Comedy Acted by his Highness the Duke of YORKES Servants.

div.p: In the SAVOY, Printed for Henry Herringman at the Sign of the Anchor in the Lower-Walk of the New 〈◊〉. 1668.

div.head: TO The thrice Noble, High and 〈◊〉 Prince WILLIAM, Duke, Marquess, and Earl of Newcastle, Earl of 〈…〉 Mansfield, Bason of 〈◊〉, of ●gle, of Bertram, B●thall, and Hepple, Gentleman of His Majesties Bed-chamber, One of His Majesties most honourable Privy Councel, Knight of the most noble Order of the Garter, His Majesties Lieutenant of the County and Town of Nottingham, and Justice in Eyre, Trent North, &c.
div.p:
HAd I no particular Obligations to ●rg● me, yet my own Inclinations would prompt me not onely to dedicate this to you, but my self to your Graces service: Since you have so much obliged your Countrey both by your Courage, and your Wit, that all men who pret●●● either to Sword, or Pen, ought to shelter themselves under your Graces Protection: Those Excellencies, as well▪
as the great Obligations I have had the honour to receive from your Grace, are the occasion of this Dedication: And I doubt not, but that Generosity wherewith your Grace has alwayes succour'd the afflicted, will make you willing (by suffering me to use the honour of your name) to rescue this from the bloody hands of the Criticks, who will not dare to use it roughly, when they see your Graces name in the beginning, that being a stamp sufficient to render it true Coyn, though it be adulterate. That authority that makes you able, and that great Goodness that makes you willing to protect all your servants, may give you frequent troubles of this nature, but I hope your Grace will be pleased to pardon them when they come from

closer.signed: Your Graces Most obliged humble servant, Tho. Shadwell.

div.head: PREFACE.
div.p:
THe success, of this Play, as it was much more then it deserv'd, so was much more than I expected: Especially in this very Critical age, when every man pretends to be a Judge, and some, that never read Three Playes in their lives, and never understood one, are as positive in their Judgement of Playes, as if they were all Iohnsons. But had I been us'd with all the severity imaginable, I should patiently have submitted to my Fate; not like the rejected Authors of our time, who when their▪ Playes are damn'd, will strut, and huff it out, and laugh at the Ignorance of the Age: Or like some other of our Modern 〈◊〉 that declare they are resolv'd to justifie their Playes with their Swords (though perhaps their Courage is as little as their Wi●● such as peep through their loop-holes in the Theatre, to see who looks grum upon their Playes: and if they spy a Gentle Squire making Faces, he poor soul must be Hector'd till he likes 'em, while the more stubborn Bully-Rock damm's,
and is safe: 〈…〉 in 〈◊〉 choice of 〈…〉 had 〈◊〉 pretend they cannot 〈…〉 will 〈◊〉, and look big upon the success of an ill play 〈◊〉 full of Songs and Dances, (which have that constraint upon 'em too, that they seldome seem to come in willingly;) When in such Playes the Composer and the Dancing-Master are the best Poets, and yet the unmerciful Scribler would rob the● of all the Honour.

I am so far from valuing my self (as 〈…〉) upon this Play, that perhaps no man is a 〈…〉 of it then my self; yet if any thing 〈…〉 made me proud of it, It would have 〈…〉 Favour and Countenance it receiv'd from His Majesty and their Royal Highnesses.

But I could not perswade my self that they were so favourable to the Play for the Merit of it, but out of a Princely Generosity, to encourage a young●beginner, that did what he could to please them, and that otherwise might have been baulk'd for ever: 'Tis to this I owe the success of the Play, and am as far from presumption of my own merits in it, as one ought to be who receives an Alms.

The first hint I receiv'd was from the report of a Play of Molieres of three Acts, called Les Fasch●●x▪ upon which I wrote a great part of this before I read that; And after it came to my hands, I found so little for my use (having before upon that hint design'd
the 〈…〉 I have made use of but two short 〈◊〉 (Viz▪) the first Scene in the Second Act between Stafford and Roger, and Molier's story of Piquette, which I have translated into Back-gammon, both of them so vary'd you would not know them. But I freely confess my Theft, and am asham'd on't, though I have the example of some that never yet wrote Play without stealing most of it; And (like Men that lye so long▪ till they believe themselves) at length, by continual▪ Thieving, reckon their stolne goods their own too▪ which is so ignoble a thing, that I cannot but believe that he that makes a common practice of stealing other mens Witt, would, if he could, with the same safety steale any thing else.

I have in this Play, as neer as I could, observed the three Unities, of Time, Place, and Action; The time of the Drama does not exceed six houres, the place is in a very narrow Compass, and the Main-Action of the Play, upon which all the rest depend, is the Sullen-Love betwixt Stanford and Emilia, which kind of love is onely proper to their Characters: I have here, as often as I could naturally, kept the Scenes unbroken, which (though it be not so much practised, or so well understood, by the English) yet among the French-Poets is accompted a great Beauty; but after these frivolous excuses the want of design in the Play has been objected against me; which fault (though I may endeavour a little to extenuate) I
dare not absolutely deny: I conceive, with all submission to better Judgments, that no man ought to expect such Intrigues in the little actions of Comedy, as are requir'd in Playes of a higher Nature: but in Playes of Humour, where there are so many Characters as there are in this, there is yet less design to be expected: for, if after I had form'd three or four forward prating Fopps in the Play, I had made it full of Plott, and Business; at the latter end, where the turnes ought to be many, and suddenly following one another, I must have let fall the humour, which I thought wou'd be pleasanter then Intrigues could have been without it; and it would have been easier to me to have made a Plott then to hold up the Humour.

Another Objection, that has been made by some, is, that there is the same thing over and over: which I do not apprehend, unless they blame the unity of the action, yet Horace de Arte Poetica, sayes, Sit quod vis, simplex duntaxat, & unum. Or whether it be the carrying on of the humours to the last, which the same Author directs me to doe.
Si quid inexpertum Scenae committis, & audes
Personam formare novam, Ser●et●● ad Imu●●
Qualis ab incepto processerit, & sibi constet.

I have endeavour'd to represent variety of Humours (most of the persons of the Play differing in their Characters from one another) which was the practise of Ben Iohnson, whom I think all Drammatick Poets ought to imitate, though none are like to come near; he being the onely person that appears to me to have made perfect Representations of Humane Life: most other Authors that I ever read, either have wilde Romantick Tales, wherein they strein Love and Honour to that Ridiculous height, that it becomes Burlesque: or in their lower Comoedies content themselves with one or two Humours at most, and those not near so perfect Characters as the admirable Iohnson alwayes made, who never wrote Comedy without seven or eight considerable Humours. I never saw one except that of Falstaffe that was in my judgment comparable to any of Iohnson's considerable Humours: You will pardon this digression when I tell you he is the man, of all the World, I most passionately admire for his Excellency in Drammatick- Poetry.

Though I have known some of late so Insolent to say, that Ben Iohnson wrote his best Playes without Wit; imagining, that all the Wit in Playes consisted in bringing two persons upon the Stage to break Jests, and to bob one another, which they call Repartie, not considering that there is more wit and invention requir'd in the finding out good Humor, and
Matter 〈…〉 reparties. For, 〈…〉 of a Humor, ● Man is confin'd not to 〈◊〉 from the Character, and oblig'd to say nothing but what is proper to it: but in the Playes which have been 〈◊〉 of late, there is no such thing as perfect Character, but the two chief persons are most commonly a Swearing, Drinking, Whoring, Ruffian for a Lover, and an impudent ill-bred tonirig for a Mistress, and these are the fine people of the Play; and there is that Latitude in this, that almost any thing is proper for them to say; but their chief Subject is bawdy, and profaness, which they call brisk writing, when the most dissolute of Men, that rellish those things well enough in private, are chok'd at e'm in publick: and, methinks, if there were nothing but the ill Manners of it, it should make Poets avoid that Indecent way of Writing.

But, perhaps you may think me as impertinent as any one I represent; that, having so many faults of my own, shou'd take the liberty to Judge of others, to impeach my fellow Criminalls: I must confess it is very ungenerous to accuse those that modestly confess their own Errors; but positive men, that Justifie all their faults, are Common Enemies, that no man ought to spare, prejudicial to all Societies they live in, destructive to all Communication, alwayes indeavouring Magisterially to impose upon our understandings, against the Freedome of Mankind: These ought no more to be 〈◊〉 amongst us, then wild beasts:
for no corrections that can be laid upon e'm are of power to reforme e'm; and certainly it was a positive Foole that Salomon spoke of, when he said, bray him in a Mortar, and yet he will retain his folly.

But I have troubled you too long with this Discourse, and am to aske your pardon for it, and the many faults you will find in the Play; and beg you will believe, that whatever I have said of it, was intended not in Justification, but Excuse of it: Look upon it, as it really was, wrote in haste, by a Young Writer, and you will easily pardon it; especially when you know that the best of our Drammatick Writers have wrote very ill Playes at first, nay some of e'm have wrote several before they could get one to be Acted; and their best Playes were made wi●● great expence of labour and time. Nor can you expect a very Correct Play, under a Years pains at the least, from the Wittiest Man of the Nation; It is so difficult a thing to write well in this kind. Men of quality, that write for their pleasure, will not trouble themselves with exactness in their Playes; and those, that write for profit, would find too little incouragement for so much paines as a correct Play would require.

div.head: Prologue.
div.l: HOw popular are Poets now a dayes?
Who can more Men at their first summons raisd,
Then many a wealthy home-bred Gentleman,
By all his interest in his Countrey can.
They raise their friends, but in one day arise
'Gainst one poor Poet, all these Enemies:
For so he has observ'd you alwayes are,
And against all that write maintain a Warr.
What shall he give you composition now?
Alass, he knowes not what you will allow.
He has no cautionary-Song, nor Dance,
That might the Treaty of his Peace advance.
No kinde Romantick Lovers in his Play,
To sigh and whine out passion, such as may
Charme Waitingwomen with Heroick Chime,
And still resolve to live and die in Rhime;
Such as your Eares with Love, and Honour feast,
And play at Crambo for three houres at least:
That Fight, and wooe in Verse in the same breath,
And make Similitudes, and Love in Death:
— But if you love a fool, he bid me say,
He has great choyce to shew you in his Play;
(To doe you service) I am one to day.
VVell Gallants, 'tis his first, Faith, let it goe,
Iust as old Gamesters by young Bubbles do:
This first and smaller Stake let him but win,
And for a greater Summ you'le draw him in,
Or use our Poet, as you would a Hare,
VVhich when she's hunted down, for Sport you spare.
At length take up, and, damne no more for shame,
For if you onely at the Quarrey aime,
This Critick poaching, will destroy your Game.

list.head: DRAMMATIS PERSONAE.
list.item: Stanford,— A Morose Melancholy Man, tormented beyond Measure with the Impertinence of People, and resolved to leave the World to be quit of them.
Lovel,— An Ayery young Gentleman, friend to Stafford, one that is pleased with, an●●aughs 〈◊〉 the Impertinents, and that which is the others torment, is his recreation.

Sir Positive At-all, A foolish Knight, that pretends to understand every thing in the world, and will suffer no man to understand any thing in his Company; so foolishly Positive, that he will never be convinced of an Error, though never so grosse—

Ninny,— A conceited Poet, alwayes troubling men with impertinent Discourses of Poetry, and the repetition of his own Verses; in all his Discourse he uses such affected Words, that 'tis as bad as the Canting of a Gypsie.
VVoodcock— A Familiar loving Coxcombe, that embraces and kisses all men: so used to his Familiar endearing expressions, that he cannot forbear▪ them in the midst of his Anger.
Huffe,— An impudent Cowardly Hector that torments Stafford with coming to borrow Money, and 〈◊〉 beaten by him.
Country Gent,— A Grave ill-bred Coxcombe, that never speaks without a Proverb.
Tim. Scribble,— Iacob Dash,— Two Justices Clerkes.
Emilia,— Of the same Humour with Stanford.
Carolina,— Of the same Humour with Lovel.
Lady Vaine,— A Whore, that takes upon her the name of a Lady, very talkative and impertinently affected in her Language, alwayes pretending to Vertue and Honour.
Serjeant, with a File of Musquetiers, VVaiters, Fidlers, &c.

div.stage: The place of the SCENE LONDON.
The Time, In the Moneth of March, 1667/8.

div.head: THE Sullen Lovers: OR, THE IMPERTINENTS.
ACT. I.
div.stage: Enter Stanford and Roger his Man.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.l: IN what Unlucky Minute was I born,
To be tormented thus where e're I go?
What an Impertinent age is this we live in
When all the World is grown so troublesome,
That I shou'd envy him that spends his dayes
In some remote▪ and unfrequented Place,
With none but Bears and Wolves for his Companions,
And never see's the folly of Mankind.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Good Sir be patient, let it not disturb you,

sp.speaker: Stanford.
sp.l: Patient—
Thou may'st as well teach patience to a man
That has a fit oth' Collick or the Stone,

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: What in a fit agen Stanford? now art
Thou as moody as a Poet after his Play is Damn'd.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.l: Oh Lovel,
I am tormented so beyond my patience
I am resolv'd to quit the World, and find
Some Uninhabited place far from Converse,
Where I may live as free as Nature made me.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Why this is down right Madness,
Prethee send for a Chirurgeon and open a Veine,
Try what that will do; for thou wilt be as
Ripe for Bedlum else as a Fanatick.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.l: What would you have me do?
Where e're I turn me I am baited still
By some importunate Foole's that use me Worse,
Then Boyes do Cocks upon Shrove-Tuesday;
This makes my life so tedious and unpleasant,
That rather then endure it longer I'le find out
Some place in the West-Indies, where I may
See a Man no oftner then a Blazing-Star.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: VVhy thou wilt come to be bound in thy Bed Stanford:
‛ Thank Heav'n I find nothing makes me Weary of
My life, thou art scandalous; VVhy dost thou abuse
This Age so? me thinks, it's as pretty an Honest
Drinking-VVhoring Age as a man wou'd wish to
Live in.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.l: Sure, Lovel, thou wer't born without a Gaule,
Or bear'st thy anger like a Useless thing,
That can'st indure to live among such Fooles,
As we are every Day Condemn'd to see.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: VVhere's the trouble?

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.l: Sure thou art Insensible, or thou woud'st not ask me,
I am more restless then the Man that has
A Raging Feavor on him; and like him,
I change my place, thinking to ease my self; But find
That which should lessen does increase my pain.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: As how Sir?

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.l: Could any man have borne but yesterdayes impertinence?

sp.speaker: Lov▪
sp.l: VVhat was that, for I have not seen you since.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.l: In the morning,
Coming abroad to find you out, (the onely Friend
VVith whom I can enjoy my self) comes in a brisk
Gay Coxcomb of the Town— O Lord, Sir, (sayes he)
I am glad I've taken you within, I came on purpose
To tell you the newes, d'ye hear it? then might I
Reasonably expect to hear of some great Intrigue or
Other; At the least that the Kings of France and Spain
VVere agreed— Then after he had bid me guess
Four or five times, with a great deal of amazement
Sayes he: Jack-Scatterbrain comes in with ten Guinny's
Last night into the Groom-porters, and
Carry'd away 200, and then Teaz'd me
Half an Hour, to tell me all his Throwes.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Now, shou'd I have been pleas'd with this.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.l: You make me Mad to hear you say so.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: If you are VVeary of one Company, why don't
You try another? and vary your Companions as often
As your Young-Gallants do their Mistresses, or
The VVell-bred-Ladies their Servants.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.l: VVhere e're I go I meet the same affliction: If I go
Into the City, there I find a Company of Fellowes
Selling of their Soules for Two-pence in the Shilling
Profit.

sp.speaker: Lovell.
sp.l: You are too Satyricall.—

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.l: Besides, I find the very fools I avoid at this
End of the Town, come thither, some to take
Up Money at Ten in the hundred, what with
Interest and Brokage, as they call it; others to take
Up Commodities upon Tick, which they sell at half
Value for ready Money, and these Inhumane Raskals
I'th very midst of all their business will fix upon
Me, and I am more Barbarously us'd by e'm, then a
New-Poet by a Knot of Critticks.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: So Sir! go on with your Relation.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.l: The other day, being tyr'd almost to death with the
Impertinence of Fopps that importun'd me;
For Variety, I ventur'd into a Coffee-house;
There I found a Company of formal Starch'd-Fellows
Talking Gravely, VVisely, and nothing to the purpose;
And with undaunted Impudence discoursing of the
Right of Empires; the Mannagement of Peace and VVar;
And the great Intrigues of Councils; when o'my
Conscience you wou'd have sooner took e'm for
Tooth-Drawers then Privy-Counsellors.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: But why don't you make this
Pleasant to your self, and Laugh at e'm as I do?

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.l: 'Faith Sir, I cannot find the Jest on't.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Yet methinks however this should not make me
Uneasie to my self.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Sure, Lovell, you have patience more then ever Stoick had; This damn'd Impertinence makes me resolv'd to fly my Country; I can never find one houres refreshment in a Year: If I go to the Theatre, where all People hope to please themselves; either I find an Insupportable Play; or If a good one, ill acted; or which is worse, so many troublesome Wits buzzing about my Eares, that I am driven from thence too.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: If this torments you so, then change the Scene, and
Go to Court, where Conversation is refin'd.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.l: Why so I do; but there I find a company of gaudy nothings.
That feign would be Courtiers; that think they are
Hardly dealt withall not to have Imployment too:
Besides, when after all my persecutions, I think
To ease my self at night by sleep, as last night
About eleven or twelve of Clock; at a solemn
Funeral the Bells set out: That Men should be
Such Owles to keep five thousand
People awake, with Ringing a Peale to him that does not hear it.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: But 'tis Generously done, especially since in my
Conscience they expect no thanks for their Labour,
Neither from their Dead Friend, nor any one else.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.l: A Curse upon e'm, this was no sooner past, but
About two in the Morning comes the Bell-man,
And in a dismal Tone repeats Worse Rhymes
Then a Cast Poet of the Nursery can make; after
Him, come those Rogues that wake People with their
Barbarous tunes, and upon their Toting
Instruments make a more Hellish-Noise then they
Do at a Play-house, When they flourish for the
Entrance of Witches.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: All this disturbs not me: but if you are troubled
VVith this Noise, VVhy don't you live in the Country,
There you may be free.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Free! Yes to be drunk with March-Beer, and Wine, worse then ever was serv'd in at Pye-corner at the eating of Pigs; and hear no other Discourse, but of Horses, Dogs, and Hawkes.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: I wou'd not be of your uneasie disposition for
The World: but granting all this: Cannot the
Women of the Town please you? methinks
The pretty Devils have Charmes enough to keep me
In the VVorld still without the Danger of being
Felo-de-se.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.l: VVomen! O! name e'm not: They are impertinence
It self, I can scarce endure the sight of e'm.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: VVhy thou art stark-mad; 'faith for my part I
Ne're met with any of the Sex that was kind and
Pretty, but I cou'd bear with her Impertinence.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.l: It cannot be.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: No! wou'd thoud'st try me: And bring
Me to a New VVoman that's handsome; if I
Boggl'd at her Impertinence, may I never have
Other to help me at my Necessity, then an Oyster
VVife, or one that cries Ends of Gold and Silver:
Methinks Beauty and Impertinence do well enough
Together.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.l: Sure you railly with me all this while, you cannot
Be so stupid to think I have not reason in my
Opinion, but nothing I have ever told you yet
Has equall'd the persecution of this Day.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: I know whom that concernes— prethee let me
Hear't, that I may laugh a little at those
Monkeys; The Variety of their folly alwayes
Affords new matter▪

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: That it does, to my sad experience; This morning, just as I was coming to look for you, Sir Positive At-all, that Fool; that will let no Man understand any thing in his Company, Arrests me with his Impertinence; sayes, he, with a great deal of Gravity, perhaps I am the Man of the World that have found out two Plays, that betwixt you and I have a great deal of Wit in e'm; Those are, the Silent Woman, and the Scornful Lady— And if I understand any thing in the World, there's Wit enough, in both those, to make one good Play, if I had the management of e'm: for you must know, this is a thing I have thought upon and consider'd.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: This is the pleasant'st thing I ever heard.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.l: May you have enough on't then if you think so:
But this was not all, for notwithstanding I
Granted his Opinion, he forc'd me to stay an
Hour to hear his Impertinent Reasons for't;
But no sooner, by some happy Accident or
Other, had I got rid of him, but in comes
That familiar Loving Puppy Woodcock, that admires
Fooles for Wits, and Torments me with a damn'd
Coranto, as he calls it, upon his Violin, which he us'd
So Barbarously, I was ready to take it for a
Bag-pipe.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: This wou'd have made me broke my Spleen with
Laughter.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: I must be stung with a Tarrantula, before I cou'd laugh at it: but here my persecution did not end; For after I had got loose from the other two, whom shou'd I see as I came along, but that infinite Coxcomb Poet- Ninny: who by force of Arms hales me into his Lodging, and Reads me there a Confounded Scene in Heroick Verse: so that, what with Sir Positive's Orations, Woodcocks squeaking Fiddle, and Poet Ninny's Heroick Fustian, I have a greater VVind-mill in my brain then a New-Polititian with his head full of Reformation, but as Fate wou'd have it, in came a Dunn and out got I; and for fear of further Interruption, came back to my Lodging.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.l: O Sir! here's Poet Ninny—

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.l: I ha' but nam'd the Devil, and see I have rais'd him.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.l: Mr. Lovel, Your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Sweet Mr. Ninny, I am yours.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.l: But dear Mr. Stanford, I am infinitely troubl'd
That that unmannerly Raskal shou'd come and disturb
Us just now: but you know, Sir, we cannot help the
Impertinence of foolish Idle Fellowes.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.l: No, no! you have convinc'd me sufficiently of that.
How the Devil could he follow me? I think the
Raskal ha's as good a Nose as a Blood-Hound.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.l: I have a Coppy of heroick-Verses will fit him
I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Read e'm to him, he's a great Judge I can assure you.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.l: Sir, I am happy to meet with one that is so great
A Judge of Poetry as you are, for it is a miserable
Thing for an Author to expose his things to empty
Giddy-fellowes: and let me tell you, between you and
I, there are seven thousand Fooles to seven Wise Men.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.l: That so great a Truth should be spoken by one
That I'le swear is none of the seven.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.l: Now do you judge Lovel:
'Slife, another Teazer here! Woodcock?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Dear Ninny, Ah dear Lovel: Ah my dear Iack-Stanford, I am the happiest Man in thy Friendship of any Kisses them all. Man's upon Earth: Dear Iack, I have the greatest value for thee in the World; 'prethee Kiss me agen dear Heart.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.l: Now Lovel, Have I reason or not?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: That you have to Laugh; This is my recreation.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Well! if I do not leave the World within these three days; May I be eternally baited by Sir Positive, Ninny, and Woodcock, which is a Curse worse then the worst of my Enemies Wishes.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: Hey! Art thou resolv'd to give over the World too
Dear Heart; There's a Lady that came to Town
Yesterday that is of the same mind; she told me
So, but I hope she will not, for the truth on't is
Jack, I am in Love with her.

sp.speaker: Ninny.
sp.p: Are you so? but I hope I shall catch her from you for all that.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: She sayes she's so troubled with Impertinent People, which between you and I Iack, are so numerous in this Town, that a Man cannot live in quiet for e'm, that she's resolv'd to leave the World to be quit of e'm.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.l: Yes, Faith she told me so last night as I was reading
A Scene of my Play to her.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.l: No doubt she had reason.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.l: 'Tis your Acquaintance Ned Lovel, Carolina's Sister,
Emilia.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.l: Now Stanford I'le oblige you, and bring you
Acquainted with this Lady; Certainly her humour
Will please you.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.l: My Friend torment me too! Have I not impertinent
Acquaintance enough already; but you must endeavour
To trouble me with more.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.l: VVell! that's an Excellent Coppy of
Verses of thine: Dear Ninny. Come on Iack,
Thou shalt hear e'm.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.l: Hell and Damnation!

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.l: Hold, hold; You shall hear
Your sad indifference (Look you Sir, 'tis upon a
Lady, that is indifferent in her Carriage tow'rd me)
Your sad indifference— (I am confident this
VVill please you, here are many thoughts I was happy in,
And the Choice of VVords not unpleasant, which you
Know is the greatest matter of all)— Your sad indifference
So wounds— (Look you, you shall find as much
Soul and Force, and Spirit, and Flame in this, as ever you
Saw in your Life.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.l: Come Iack hear't, it is a most admirable piece.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.l: Now, Lovel, What think you.
Gentlemen, I have Extraordinary business,
I must leave you.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.l: No, no, hold! Faith thou shalt stay and hear
His Verses, they are as good as ever were read;
Come Ninny—

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.l: O Devil! VVhat have I deserv'd to have this
Inflicted upon me.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.l: Reads. Your sad indifference so wounds my fair
At once, I hope, and do at once despair.
How do you like that, ha?—
You do at once both hate and kindness show;
And are at once both Kind and Cruel two.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: O! Very fine! Is't not Ned?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: O! Extreame fine.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.l: What the Devil makes you commend these sottish
Verses, that are nothing but a Iingling of Words?
Let's go.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.l: Reads Agen. Hold! hold! hold, hear the rest; hem—
At once my hopes you nourish, and destroy
My onely grief, and yet my onely Joy.
Mark that?

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.l: O Devil!

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.l: Reads. Vertue and Vice at once in you do shine;
Your Inclinations are, and are not mine.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: O Admirable! Didst ever hear any thing so
Fine in thy life Dear Heart?

sp.speaker: ‛ Stan.
sp.l: Ninny Reads agen. O how these Curs bait me?
At once a storme and calme I do espy,
And do at once a smile and frown descry.
At once you kindle and put out my flame:
I cold, as Ice, as hot as Charcoal am.
Mark that Mr. Stanford, I was very happy in that
Thought, as I hope to breath.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: Upon my Word, Iack, that's a great flight of his.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Sir, methinks there's as pretty a Soul in't, as a Man shall see in a Summers Day.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.l: What am I condemn'd to?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Why do you torment your self thus, methinks nothing can be pleasanter.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.l: Gentlemen, detain me not, I'le stay no longer.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Dear Mr. Stanford, I ha' just done, if you have any respect in the World for me, stay and hear the end on't.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: Nay, 'Faith Iack thou shalt stay.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.l: What's this I endure?

sp.speaker: Ninny
sp.l: Reads. My Fate at once is gentle and severe,
You will not show your hate, nor Love declare:
Such safety and such dangers in your eye,
That I resolve at once to live and die.
There's, Body and Soul, in that Couplet.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Hey; riddle me riddle me this, but this is the
Fashionable way of writing.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.l: What say you, Sir? Are they not well? You are a great
Judge.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.l: Pray Sir let me go, I am no Judge at all, let me go,
I will not stay.
Sir Positive, here! I had rather
Goe against an Insurrection of 'Prentices, then
Encounter him.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: Ah Dear Iack! Have I found thee? I would not but have seen you for twenty pound: I have made this morning a glorious Corrant, an immortal Corrant, a Corrant with a Soul in't; I'le defy all Europe to make such another: You may talk of your Baptists, your Locks, and your Banisters; let me see e'm Mend this: Why here's at least 25 Notes Compass, Fa la, la, &c. You shall hear.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: Come, Sir Positive, lets hear't.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.l: With all my heart: Fa, la, la.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.l: Oh Heaven! Sir Positive, though I love Musick,
Yet at present I must tell you,
I am out of Tune.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.l: Out of Tune, Ha, ha, ha,— Now have you said the
Best thing in the World, and do not know it.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Sir Positive, I must take my leave of you, I must not lose my Business for a little Musick.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.l: Hold, now you talk of Musick!—

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.l: 'Slife, Sir, I talk of my Business.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: But for Musick, if any Man in England gives you a better account to that then I do, I will give all mankind leave to spit upon me: You must know it's a thing I have thought upon and consider'd, and made it my business from my Cradle; besides, I am so naturally a Musitian, that Gamut, A re, Bemi, were the first words I could learn to speak: Do you like Baptist's way of Composing?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: No doubt, Sir, he's a great Master.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.l: As ever was born, take that from me.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: Upon my Word, Stanford, I will make all my Tunes like his— You shall hear his Vein in this Corrant now.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.l: One trouble upon the neck of another— When
I shall be deliver'd from these Fooles?

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.l: Do but ask Ninny there?

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Yes doubtless, Sir Positive has a great Soul of Musick in him; he has great power In Corranto's and Jiggs, and composes all the Musick to my Playes he ha's great power.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: As any man that ever was born, Dear Heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.l: Come, you shall hear't—

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.l: Sir, I beg your pardon; I'le hear it some other time.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.l: Pish, pish, Upon my Hononr thou shalt stay,
And hear it now.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Come, Dear Sir Positive, Make us happy.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.l: Observe! here's Flame in this Corrant— Fa, la, la.
There's a delicate Note in B, Fa Bemi in Alt,
And observe now how it falls down to C. Sol. Fa. Ut.
Fa, la, la— There's Mastery for you.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.l: I do not like that part of your Corrant.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit▪
sp.p: It is a prodigious thing, thou shou'dst ever be in my Company, and understand Musick no better; thou hast found fault with the best part of the Corrant, ask Woodcock else?

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.l: By the Lord Harry, there is a great deal of
Glory in that part of the Corrant.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.l: Observe here how cunningly it falls out of the Key,
And now at last it ends quite out of the Key.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.l: Well, well! it's an Excellent Corrant; What the Devil
Will you have more?— Fare you well.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.l: No, no; Stay but one Minute and you shall hear it
All together. Ninny, Do you beat Time—

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.l: Well thought on, do, and I'le Dance
To't Dear Hearts.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Now, Lovel, What think you, this Torture's worse then any the Dutch invented at Amboyna.

div.stage: Sir Positive sings, Ninny beats, False Time & Woodcock Dances to't.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.l: Here's a Corrant for you, ha! Stanford,
What think'st of this?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: Think quoth a', I think I danc'd it as well
As any Man in England, Bully-Rock.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Certainly, Sir Positive, he Dances very finely.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.l: As any man that ever was born upon two Leggs▪
I defie any Man in the World that out-does him;
For betwixt you and I, I taught him every step he has.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Upon my Word, Woodcock, you have as much power
In Dancing, as any Man in England.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: Dear Heart let me Kiss thee; Gad thou art a great
Judge— Here, drink my Health.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Ah! Dear Flattery, How convenient a sin art thou?

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Come, Mr. Woodcock, you shall go to the reading of my Play.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: Ay! Come on, Bully-Rock—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Come, I'le take pity on you, Stanford, and go before, and prepare some place or other, where we may enjoy our selves, and you be free. I'le take your Man along with me, and send him back agen in haste for you; by that means you may get loose.—

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.l: For Heavens sake make hast, you'l oblige me for ever.
Sir Positive! I am sorry I must leave you now;
I must go speak with a Gentleman that came
From Flanders last night.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: Flanders! If any Man gives you that account of Flanders that I do, I'le suffer Death; You must know I have thought of their Affairs, I have consider'd the thing throughly, never speak on't more, name it no more, let it not enter into your Thoughts; 'tis a lost Nation, absolutely undone, lost for ever, take that from me: and yet were I with Castel Rodrigo but one quarter of an hour, I'de put him in a way to save all yet.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.l: This is beyond all sufferance.— Sir Positive, I am
So much in haste, that none but your self shou'd
Have staid me of all Mankind.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p:
Mankind! Dost thou know what thou say'st now? Do'st thou talk of Mankind? I am confident thou never so much as thought'st of Mankind in thy life: I'le tell thee, I will give Dogs leave to piss upon me, if any man understands
Mankind better then my self, now you talk of that. I have consider'd all Mankind, I have thought upon nothing else but Mankind this Moneth; and I find you may be a Poet, a Musitian, a Painter, a Divine, a Mathematician, a States-man; but betwixt you and I, let me tell you, we are all Mortal.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Well, they may talk of the Pox, want of Money, and a Scoulding Wife, but they are Heaven to my afflictions.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: Sir Positive, my Lady Vaine desires you wou'd come And look upon her Picture that's come this Morning from Master Lilly's.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: Why there 'tis now Stanford, that people shou'd have no more Judgement, she had as good have thrown her Money into the Dirt; 'tis true, I cou'd have made him have made a good picture on't, if I had drawn the Lines for him, but I was not thought worthy, and now you talk of Painting, either I am the greatest Fopp in Nature, or if I do not understand that, I understand nothing in the World: why I will paint with Lilly, and draw in little with Cooper for 5000 l▪

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: O! intollerable Impertinence! I am affraid he will not go now his Mistress sends for him.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.l: Dear Stanford! I must beg thy Excuse—

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.l: A Curse on him, that's easily granted.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: Come Mistress Bridget I'le go along with you.— Dear Stanford take it not unkindly, for I wou'd not leave thee but upon this occasion.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.l: A thousand Thanks to the occasion.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: But you know a man must not disoblige his Mistress Iack?

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.l: Oh no, by no means.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.l: Adien.—

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.l: So! this Trouble is over.
O Fate! how little care you took of me,
By these Misfortunes I too plainly see.

div.head: ACT. II.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: I Long to bring 'em together, they will be well Match'd; but we must stay awhile, for she ha's been so teaz'd this morning, she ha's lock'd her self up in her Chamber.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Stanford was ready to fall out with me, when I nam'd a new acquaintance to him, and will not be perswaded there is such a Creature as a Woman:
sp.l: That is not Impertinent.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Emilia is as Cautious as he can be, and wou'd be ready To swound at the sight of a new face, for she will not believe but all mankind are Coxcombs: for Heav'ns sake Lovell let's surprize them into one anothers Company, we shall have admirable sport.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Wee'l do't; but Madam, why shou'd we mind their bus'ness that have enough of our own: what if you and I shou'd play the fools once in our Lives, and enter into the bonds of Wedlock together.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Fy, fy, 'tis such a Constant condition of life, that a Woman had as good be profest in a Nunnery, for she can no sooner get out of one then t'other.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: But with your pardon, Madam, this is somewhat The pleasanter Condition of the Two.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: That's according as they use both Conditions, but
Pray Master Lovell bring not this villanous Matrimony
Into dispute any more, lest that may make us desire
It, I have known some men by maintaining a
Heresie in Jest become of that opinion in good Earnest.
But do you know that my Lady Vaine was here this Morning?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: No Madam; but what of that?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: She told me that of you will make your Ears tingle.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Of me, Madam, what was't?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: She sayes you are the most inconstant man, the most perfidious Wretch that e're had breath, and bid me fly you as I wou'd infection.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: What the Devil did she mean by that?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Come, let me know what's betwixt you, or I'le
Rack you but I'le know it.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: This Jealousie makes me believe you love me.
That she should be prating her self,
How many Women would be thought honest, if
They could hold their own Tongues.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I am like to have a fine servant of you: but a Lady wou'd have a fine time on't that were to marry you, to stake all the treasures of her Youth and Virginity, which have been preserv'd with so much Care, and Heav'n knows some trouble too against nothing.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Faith Madam, I have e'en as much as I had before, but if you'l be kind, I'le take that Care off your hands, and soon rid you of that trouble.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: No, no, go to my Lady Vaine, give her your Heart poor Lady she wants it too but for me, I can keep my affliction to my self.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Dear Carolina! name her no more, if you do, I will get drunk immediately. And then I shall have Courage enough to fall aboard her.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Lord! what a loss shall I have: Heav'n send me patience, or I shall ne're out-live it, to loose so proper a Gentleman, but why should I think to rob her of her due, no, no, now I think on't to her again, go, go.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: For Heav'ns sake Carolina do not Tyrannize thus, why I had rather be kept waking at an ill Play then endure her Company.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Thus are we poor Women despis'd when we give away our Hearts to ungrateful men, but Heav'n will punish you.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Dear Carolina, let's leave fooling, and be in down-right Earnest.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I hope, Sir, your Intentions are honourable.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Madam, why should you once doubt it?
My Love to you is as pure as the flame that burns upon an Altar:
You are too unjust if you suspect my honour.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Now will you leave fooling; on my Conscience
He is in Earnest.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: As much as the severest Anchorite can be at his Devotions.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: O! are you so, ' its a hard Case, but pray you, Sir, leave off, I had rather hear a silenc'd Parson preach sedition then you talk seriously of Love, wou'd you cou'd see how it becomes you; why you look more Comically then an old fashion'd fellow singing of Robin Hood or Chevy Chace.
My Love to you's as pure as the flame that burns upon an Altar! how scurvily it sounds.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: You are the Cruellest Tyrant alive: Let us be serious a little, I have rallied my self into a passion will ruine my else.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Come, in what posture must I stand to hear you talk formally.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: On my Conscience 'tis easier to fix quick-silver than your humour, Madam, but if you wou'd enter into Wedlock I can assure you that will bring you to gravity.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Let me but once more hear you name Marriage, and I protest I'le send for my Lady Vaine to you. I tell you again I will not marry. I love your Conversation, and your humour of all things in the World.
But for Marriage 'tis good for nothing, but to make Friends fall out.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Nay, faith if you be at that I can do you the same Civility without the Ceremony, as you say it is a kind of formal Thing.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: No! I shall take Example by my Lady Vaine, poor Lady, she little thought to be unkindly us'd, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Again that name.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Besides, if we were Marry'd you might say; faith Carolina is a pretty Woman, and has humour good enough, but a pox on't she's my wife; no, no, I'le have none of that.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Do you still distrust my Honour, 'tis unkindly done, but—

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Hold, hold, her door opens, step you in there, and you may hear how she entertains the motion.

div.stage: Enter Emilia with a Book in her hand.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: The Wisdom of this Charles the fifth was
Wonderful;
Who 'midst of all his Triumphs and his Greatness,
When he had done what glory had oblig'd him to,
Seeing the Vanity of Mankind did quit
The pleasures that attend a Monarchs state;
Nay more, the most bewitching thing call'd power,
And left the World to live an humble life,
Free from the Importunity of Fools, was't not
VVisely done Sister?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Yes, no doubt on't, as wisely done to go to a Monastery to shun fools, as to keep Company with Usurers and Brokers to avoid Knaves.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: Thou art a Foolish Girl, I am tormented
With The Impertinence of both Sexes so,
I am resolv'd I'le not stay one VVeek out of a Nunnery.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: O' my Conscience thou art stark out of thy Wits with reading of Burton's Melancholly; To a Nunnery to avoyd Impertinence? where canst thou think to meet with more then there?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: Now you are too Censorious.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: You shou'd like me the better.
But you must needs find relief there? Doe you
Think any Women that have sence, or Warmth
Of blood, as we have, wou'd go into a Nunnery?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: If I shou'd meet with Fops there too,
I should be irreparably lost: Oh Heaven! what
Shall I do to ease my self? rather then
Indure the persecution of those fools that haunt
Us here. I will go where neither Man nor Woman
ever came.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: O Rare! Stanford, here's just thy Counterpart (Within. To a hair.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
Since thou art resolv'd to sequester thy self from Company, I'le buy thee a Cage and hang thee up by the Parrot over
the way, and thou shalt converse with none but him: I hope he's not Impertinent too?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: Must you torment me too? fy Sister.
What would you have me do? my Patience
Is not great enough to endure longer, to see
The folly of this age; Do you judge, after I had been
Sufficiently worry'd by the Lady Vaine this Morning,
Whom I was forc'd to get rid of, by Telling her, her
Lover my Cozen Positive was at her lodging, which
You know is as far as the Pall-mall.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: That Vertuosa as she calls her self, is the pleasantest Creature I ever saw: but prethee Sister, let me hear none of your fantastick Stories, methinks you are as Impertinent as any body.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: It distracts me to see this folly in things that are intended for reasonable Creatures.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: O Stanford! If this Lady does not match thee the devils in't.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: These Fools you talk of afford me so much recreation,
That I do not know how I should laugh without e'm.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: Thou hast no sence, they make me weary of the World!
Heav'n! what shall I do?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I tell you: Stanford hearing of your humour, and Admiring it ha's a great desire to see you, before you resolve to leave the world, try how he will please you.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: What a ridiculous thing it is of you to wish me to new Acquaintance, when I am leaving the old? I am sure He's Impertinent, for all mankind I have met are so

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Hist Lovell!

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Your humble Servant Lady's—.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: Is this he? then farewell.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Madam! pray stay, and give me the honour of one word with you.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: I knew what he was: my Lady Vaine here?

sp.speaker: La. Vaine.
sp.l: Master Lovell! your most humble servant.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Your Ladiships humble servant▪ how I hate the sight of her in presence of my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Lovell! for shame be civil to your Mistress: L●●'s hear you make Love a little.

sp.speaker: La. Vaine.
sp.p: Madam upon my Reputation there was no such thing, Sir Positive was never there, sure some Dirty fellow or other brought a false Message on purpose to rob me of the pleasure of your Ladiships sweet Company: would he were hang'd for his pains, he passion he has put me in, has put me out of Breath.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Lord! how soon she's put in and put out!

sp.speaker: La. Vain.
sp.p: But, Madam, assoon as ever I found he was not there I made all possible haste to wait upon you again, for fear your Ladiship shou'd resent my too abrubt departure.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: O Heav'ns! take pity of my afflictions, Madam—

sp.speaker: La. Vain.
sp.p: But the truth on't is I design'd to spend this day with you, since I can be no where so well satisfi'd as with your Ladiships Converse, a person who is Mistress of so much vertue and honour, which are Treasures I value above the World.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: Why, Madam—

sp.speaker: La. Vain.
sp.p: For the truth is so few Ladies have either, that they are things to be valu'd for their rarity.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Oh Impertinence! whither will this Eternal tongue of hers carry her.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: This is very pleasant for her to name Vertue and Honour In my Company.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: Madam! for Heav'ns sake—

sp.speaker: La. Vain.
sp.p: For the truth on't is, Madam, a Lady without Vertue and Honour is altogether as detestable as a Gentleman without Wit or Courage.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: Madam! I am sorry I cannot wait on you longer,
I am ingag'd to dine abroad.

sp.speaker: La. Vain.
sp.p: Where is't Madam, for I am resolv'd to go along with you.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: Why, Madam, you do not know the persons.

sp.speaker: La. Vain.
sp.p: That's all one for that, let me alone to make my Apology.

sp.speaker: Emill.
sp.l: This is beyond all suff'rance.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.l: I hope she will not leave her off so.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.l: No: if she does, I am mistaken.

sp.speaker: La Vain.
sp.l: Come, Madam; Lets go.

sp.speaker: Emili.
sp.l: But Madam, I must call at the Exchange first,
To buy some trifles there.

sp.speaker: La. Vain.
sp.l: O Madam! I'le bring you to my Milliner, that
Calls himself the Italian Milliner, or the Little
Exchange; he's better provided then any one
In the Exchange.

sp.speaker: Emili.
sp.l: I am on the sudden taken ill, and must retire.

sp.speaker: La. Vain.
sp.p: Madam, d'ye think, I that am a Virtuosa understand no better, then to leave you now you are not well; What's your Distemper? no Woman in England was more serviceable among her Neighbours then I with my Flos Unguentorum, Paracelsian and Green-salve.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: And your Album Graecum I warrant you▪

sp.speaker: La. Vain.
sp.l: That Album Graecum was a Salve of my Invention:
But a propos, perhaps it may be a fit of the Mother,
If it be, we must burn some Bl●w-Inckle, and Partridge
Feathers under your Nose; or she must smell to Asra foetida,
And have some Cold Water with a little Flower to drink:
Ay, ay, 'twill be so; pray Mr. Lovel come and help to hold her.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.l: No, no, Madam; there's no such thing I'le assure you:
I must beg leave to go to my Chamber.

sp.speaker: La. Vain.
sp.l: Come, Madam, I'le conduct you, and be as careful of you
As if you were my Sister a thousand times.

sp.speaker: Emilia.
sp.l: Madam! with your pardon, I desire to be alone, and
Try to rest.

sp.speaker: La. Vain.
sp.l: Alone! by no means in the World, Madam, it may
Be very dangerous; I would not for all the World
Madam, you shou'd be alone; suppose you shou'd
Fall into a Fit alone, I can speak it by Experience;
'Tis Dangerous for a Lady to fall into a Fit without
An Able Body by her. Come, Madam, I'le conduct you in.

sp.speaker: Emilia.
sp.l: How shall I get rid of her▪

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Let's in and see when the Fury of this Dol Comon will be at an End.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.l: Come, come, we shall have the pleasure of seeing my
Sister Worry'd almost to Death

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.l: I wonder my Man returnes not yet.
I thought to have found Mr. Lovel here, but
Here's one will do my business.

sp.speaker: Huffe.
sp.l: Oh Mr. Stanford! Have I found you?

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.l: Oh Heaven's! Will my punishment never end?

sp.speaker: Huffe.
sp.l: I am the most unfortunate Man that ever was born.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.l: Why do you trouble me with this? Am I the
Cause on't?

sp.speaker: Huffe.
sp.p: No! but I'le tell you, upon my Reputation, I have been Nick't out of twenty pound Just now at Spiering's, and lost seven to four, for my last Stake.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.l: What the Devill's this to me? let me go.

sp.speaker: Huffe.
sp.p: But, Sir, I'le tell you a thing that very nearly concerns you.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.l: Some other time; 'Slife do not disturb me now.

sp.speaker: Huff.
sp.l: For Heaven's sake hear me, you'l repent it else.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.l: Make haste then, keep me in pain no longer.

sp.speaker: Huffe.
sp.p: Why, I have found out the finest plump fresh Girle, newly come out of the Country.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Hell and Damnation! Why do you trouble me with such trifles.

sp.speaker: Huffe.
sp.l: Trifles, Does he call 'em? Well! I see this won't do:
But, Sir, I'le tell you somewhat concernes you more▪
Nearly; Sir, it concernes your Honour.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.l: My Honour! Why, who dares call it in question?

sp.speaker: Huffe.
sp.l: Not so, Sir; but, Do you love Generosity and Honour?

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.l: Why do you ask the question?

sp.speaker: Huffe.
sp.p: Why then I'le put you in a way to do a very Generous▪ And Honourable thing.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.l: What do you mean by this Impertinence?

sp.speaker: Huffe.
sp.l: If you will relieve an Honest Gentleman in distress,
Lend me two Pieces, you shall have e'm agen within
Four and twenty houres, or may I perish.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.l: ‛ Pox on you for an Owl: There, take em; I wou'd
I cou'd get rid of all my Impertinents at as cheap
A rate.

sp.speaker: Huffe.
sp.l: I give you a thousand thanks.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.l: 'Slife! trouble me no more, be gone!

sp.speaker: Huffe.
sp.l: Sir, It were a very ungrateful thing not to
Acknowledge the favour.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.l: Away, away, and let your gratitude alone,

sp.speaker: Huffe.
sp.l: D'hear, Mr. Stanford! upon mine honor I'le
sp.stage: Huff offers to go out, and returns
sp.l: Return e'm tomorrow night without fail.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.l: Curse on you for a Rascal
So, here's one trouble over!
Well! What's the News?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Do you earnestly desire to know, Sir?

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.l: Must I have Impertinence in my own Family too?

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: O! I am so out of breath, I am not able to speak one word; but if I had never so much breath, I cou'd tell you nothing but what you'd be glad to hear: If I had the winde of an Irish Foot-man, nay, of a Non-conforming Parson— or.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.l: Or, with a Pox to you, one Similitude more, and I'le
Break that Fooles head of yours.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: VVell, Sir, since you are in haste, I'le be brief as a Fidler, after he's paid for scraping, for I love to be so in Cases of this Importance, for I have heard—

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.l: Out you Dog, a Sentence after your Similitude;
You are as impertinent as a Country Witness.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.l: I have done, Sir, and now I'le tell you in one VVord:
Hold Sir! here's a Spider in your Perriwigg.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.l: Death, you Rascal! I'le ram it down your Throat.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.l: Be patient, Sir: Seneca advises to moderate our passions.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.l: Hang ye ' Rascal! Seneca is an Ass in your mouth.
Tell me quickly, Or—

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.l: Why, Sir, you are so impatient you will not hear me?

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.l: 'Faith but I will speak.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Not to boast of my diligence, which, though I say it, is as much—

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: You Dogg tell me quickly, or I'le cut your Eares off.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Why Mr. Lovel, wou'd have you come to him; What wou'd you have?

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: If I were not in haste, Sirrah; I'de teach you to know your Man, and who you may put your Tricks on, you impudent Raskal.

div.stage: As Stanford is going out, enter Woodcock.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Death! That I shou'd find impertinence in others, and not see it in my self.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Dear Iack, thy humble Servant: How dost doe? My Footman told me, he saw thy Man come in here, which made me believe I shou'd find thee here; and I had not power to stay from thee, my Dear Bully-Rock, for I can enjoy my self no where so well as in thy Company: Let me kiss thee Dear Heart; 'Gad I had rather kiss thee then any Woman.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: This is beyond all Example: Oh horrid! his kindness is a greater persecution then the Injuries of others.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I'le tell thee, Dear Heart, I love thee with all my heart: thou art a man of Sence, Dear Rogue, I am infinitely happy in thy Friendship; for I meet with so many impertinent silly Fellows every day, that a man cannot live in quite for e'm: Dear Heart. For between you and I, this Town is more pester'd with idle Fellows, that thrust themselves into Company, then the Country is with Attorny's; Is it not Iack?

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Yes! I have too much reason to believe you, a Curse on you.—

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Ay, Did not I tell you so, Iack! ha? but this is not my business▪ Dear Rascal kiss me, I have a secret to impart to thee, but if it take the least Ayre, I am undone: I have a project in my head shall raise me 20000 l. I know you will promise secresy, dear heart.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.l: Don't trouble me with it.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: No, it concernes thee Man: why, thou shalt go halfes with me, Dear Heart.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: For Heaven's sake, Sir, don't trust it with me, I have a faculty of telling all I know: I cannot help it.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p:
Oh! Dear Bully-Rock, that Wheadle won't pass.
Don't I know thou art a Man of Honour; and besides, so reserv'd, that thou wilt scarce tell a secret to thy Friend.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Sir, I am unhappy in your good opinion, this is beyond all suff'rance.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: No, Faith, Dear Iack, thou deserv'st it; but my project is this, d'yee see.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Well! I am so tormented with Impertinent Fellowes, that I see there is no remedy.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: As I hope to Live, Iack, I am of thy Opinion: the ' truth on't is, 'tis intollerable, for a man can never be free from these Fooles in this Town; I like thy resolution so well, that I am a Son of a Whore if I don't go along with thee! Ah how we shall enjoy our selves when we are both together, how we shall despise the rest of the World: Dear Heart.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: O, Mr. VVoodcock! Poet Ninny is gone to the Rose Taverne, and bid me tell you, he has extraordinary business with you, and begs you wou'd make all possible hast to him.

sp.speaker: wood.
sp.p: O Dear Rascal, kiss me! thou art the honestest Fellow in the World: Dear Iack, I must beg thy pardon for a few minutes, but I hope thou'lt not take it ill; why 'tis about business Dear Heart, you know we must not neglect that.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.l: O no Sir, by no meanes.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Nay, Dear Rogue, be not angry, prethee kiss me; as I hope to live, I'le return immediately; Dear Iack, thy humble Servant—

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.l: This is a lucky Accident.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Sir, I was fain to sin a little for you, and get rid of him by this lie.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Well! this shall excuse all your former Errors, 'Ile away, for fear some other fooles shou'd find me out.

div.stage: Enter Emilia, La. Vaine (following her up and down) after them, Carolina, Lovel.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.l: Does she not Tease her bravely Lovel?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Admirably! Oh that Stanford were here! if't were for nothing but to see a fellow-sufferer.

sp.speaker: La. Vain.
sp.p: Then Madam, will your Ladyship be pleas'd to let me wait on you to a Play, there are two admirable Playes at both Houses; and let me tell you, Madam, Sir Positive, that understands those things as well as any man in England, sayes, I am a great Judge.

sp.speaker: Emili.
sp.p: Madam, I beseech you ask me no more questions; I tell you, I had as live stand among the rabble, to see a Jack-pudding eate a Custard, as trouble my self to see a Play.

sp.speaker: La! Vain.
sp.p: O Fy Madam! a young Lady and hate Playes; why I'le tell you, Madam, at one House there is a huge Two handed Devil, and as brave a Fat Fryer as one wou'd wish to see in a Summers-Day; and a delicate Machin, as they call it, where one sits and sings as fine a Song: And then at t'other house there's a rare Play, with a Jigg in't, would do your heart good to see it; but if there were nothing else in't, you might have your four Shillings out in Thunder and Lightning; and let me tell you, 'tis as well worth it as one Penny's worth another.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: What have I done?

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Am I trapan'd into Womens Company?

div.stage: Offers to go out, Lov. layes hold of him.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Hold, hold, hold, Madam, here's Mr. Stanford desires to kiss your hands.

sp.speaker: Emili.
sp.l: I am in that disorder that never Woman was.

sp.speaker: La. Vain.
sp.p: O Mr. Lovel! she's falling into a fit of an Epilepsy: help all to hold her, lend me a Knife to cut her Lace.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.l: This is worse then all the rest.

sp.speaker: Lovel
sp.l: to La. Vain. Let me speak with you in the next Room in private.

sp.speaker: La. Vain.
sp.p: Sir, your most obedient servant: I shall be glad of any occasion to retire with one, for whom I have so great an affection.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: to Carolina. For Heaven's sake follow me, or I shall be in an ill condition.

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.p: I find you are an Errant Hippocrite, but I'le take you at your word for once.

div.stage: Ex. Lov. La. Vain. and Carolina▪

sp.speaker: Emili.
sp.p: I am the greatest object of pity that was ever seen: I am never free from these Importunate Fooles.

div.stage: Stanford and Emilia walk up and down, and take little notice of one another.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: I am not less afflicted, and have as much need of pitty too.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: I find no possibility of reliefe, but by leaving the World that is so full of folly.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Who would live in an age, when Fooles are Reverenc'd, and Impudence Esteem'd.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: To see a Fellow but the other day content with humble Linsey Woolsey, now have variety of Vents, Perriwiggs and Lac'd Linnen.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: One, that but the other day, could eat but one meal a day, and that at a three-penny Ordinary; now struts in State, and talks of nothing but Shattellins and Lefronds.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: In so corrupt an Age, when all mankind flatter the greatest, and oppress the least; when to be just is to be out of fashion, and to betray a friend is lawful Cunning.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: This is pleasant for her to speak against these Aside. things, as if she were not as bad as any one: Who wou'd live in such a treach'rous Age, to see this Gentleman that Courts the t'other Gentleman's Wife, meet him and embrace him; and swear he loves him above the VVorld: and he poor fool dotes extreamly upon him that does the Injury.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Now has this Fellow a design to have me think aside. him VVise: but wisdome and honesty are fool'd out of Countenance.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Now the illiterate fool despises Learning

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Nay, among the learn'd themselves, we find many that are great Schollers by Art, are most abominable Fooles by Nature.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: This shall not perswade me to believe she is not Impertinent.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Now the qualifications of a fine Gentleman are to Eate A-la-mode, drink Champaigne, Dance Jiggs, and play at Tennis.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: To love Dogs, Horses, Hawkes, Dice and Wenches, scorne Wit, break Windows, beat a Constable, ly with his Sempstress, and undoe his Taylor, it distracts me to think on't.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Now does he desire to be taken for a discreet fellow, but this will not do.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: What relief can I expect in this age▪ when men take as much paines to make themselves fooles, as others have done to get wisdome.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Nay folly is become as natural to all mankind as lust.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: VVhat shall I do? Whither shall I turne me to avoid these Fooles.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Now let's slip e'm

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.l: We shall have a very faire Course.

div.stage: Enter La. Vaine, Ninny, Lovell and Carolina.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.l: O Heaven's! Are they here?

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.l: What will become of me?

sp.speaker: Ninny
sp.l: to Emilia. O Madam, I'le tell you, Stanford pray hear once.
'Tis such a thing as never was in the World.

sp.speaker: La. Vain.
sp.p: Ay, pray Sir hear him, he's as pretty a Wit as any man in this Town, except Sir Positive I assure you.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.l: What are we condemn'd to?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: To a worse condition then Gally-slaves.

sp.speaker: Ninny.
sp.p: I was with my Bookseller, Madam, with that Heroick Poem, which I presented to your Ladyship, as an earnest of the honour I have for you; But by the way, he's an ignorant ingrateful Fellow, for betwixt you and I he has got some hundreds of pounds by some Plays and Poems of mine which he has Printed. And let me tell you, some under the Names of Beaumont, and Fletcher, and Ben. Iohnson too: but what do you think, Madam I asked the Son of a Whore for this Poem?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: O Insufferable!

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.l: What think you Stanford?

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.l: Let me go; I have no Judgment in these things.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p:
But I'le you; There are not above 10, or 12000 Lines
in all the Poem: and as I hope to be sav'd, I ask'd him but twelve pence a line one line with another.

sp.speaker: La. Vain.
sp.p: And really, Sir, that's as reasonable as he can possibly afford e'm, take that from me?

sp.speaker: Stay.
sp.p: O Devil! this is worse then a Sheerness Ague: that will give a Man some respit between the Fits.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: By my Soul, Madam, if he had been my Brother I wou'd not have abated him one penny; for you must know, there are many hundreds of Lines, that in their Intrinsick value, are worth ten shillings a Line between Father and Son; and the greatest part of e'm are worth five shillings a line: but before George very few or none but are worth three shillings a line to the veriest Iew in Christendome; they have that salt, thought, imagination, power, spirit, soul, and flame in e'm— ha!

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: What does this concern me?

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: No, but I'le tell you, Stanford, prethee hear, as I hope for mercy this Impudent Rogue told me, he would not give me two shillings for the whole Poem; an ignorant Puppy, a fellow of all the World I design'd to make, for he might have sold these Books for three shillings apiece, and I would have help'd off with 10000 of e'm, to ten thousand of my particular intimate Friends; besides, every one that had but heard of my name, which are almost all the Kings Subjects, would have bought some; so that I should not have got above six or seven hundred pound, and in a fortnights time have made this fellow an Alderman: That such ignorant Rascalls should be Judges of VVit or Sence.

sp.speaker: La. Vain.
sp.p: VVell Sir, we shall never have good VVorld unless the State Reformes these abuses.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: 'Tis very true, Madam, for this is a thing is of Consequence to the whole Nation, Stanford.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: VVhat the Devil would you have? Am I the cause of this?
No! Heav'n forbid I should say so: but Madam, I had forgot another Advantage he had had by this.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Heav'n defend me! this puts me beyond all patience.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: I'le tell you, Stanford, prethee mind me a little.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Oh now I am undone, ruin'd for ever, Sir Positive's here.

sp.speaker: Emili.
sp.p: O intollerable!

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.l: to La. Vain I heard your Ladiship was here and came to kiss your hand.
Oh Stanford, art thou here? well, how dost Cozin?
I am glad I have found you all together, I came to
Present my Lady Vaine with a musique I have made
Which his that Invention in't, I say no more but
I have been this Moneth of making it,
And you must know musique is a thing I value my
Self upon, 'tis a thing I have thought on, and consider'd,
And made my business from my Cradle.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Come Madam, now they are settl'd in their business, let's
Leave e'm.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.l: Come! you shall see it.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: Cozen! Pray let it be another time.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.l: Nay, nay, never talk of that, you shall see't now,
And let me tell you I have as much power of Invention
In musique as any man in England: Come in,

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: O Heav'n, when shall we be deliver'd from these fools?

div.stage: Enter Fidlers and play a ridiculous piece of musique.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos
sp.p: How do you like it Stanford, is it not well! what say you Cozin, ha?

sp.speaker: La. Va.
sp.l: Indeed Sir Positive, it's very agreeable.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: Upon my honour this honest fellow plaid it with a great deal of glory, he is a most incomparable Bower, he has the most luscious, the most luxurious bow-hand of any man in Europe, take that from me, and let me tell you, if any man gives you a better account of the Intrigue of the Violin, then I do, I am an Owl, a Puppy, a Coxcomb, a Logger-head, or what you will.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Sure there is Magick in this? never to be free?

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: Magick? why do you understand Magick?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: No, no, no, not I Cozen▪ O intollerable!

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: I do; if you please talk of something else, leave that to me, why I will discover lost Spoons and Linnen, resolve all horary questions, nay raise a Devil with Doctor Faustus himself, if he were alive.

sp.speaker: Ninny
sp.p: to my Lady Vain. Woodcock a Poet? a pimp is he not?

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: Whos's that speaks of pimping there: well! though I say't no man pretends to less then I do; but I cannot pass this by without manifest Injury to my self.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: This Puppy rather then not be in at all will declare himself a pimp.

sp.speaker: Lady Vaine.
sp.p: But Sir, are you such a manner of man?

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: Why Madam? did you never hear of me for this?

sp.speaker: Lady Vaine.
sp.p: No Sir! if I had—

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: If I had— ha, ha, ha— why Madam, where have you liv'd all this while.

sp.speaker: La. Vain.
sp.p: O ●y upon him, Madam, I shall lose my reputation if I be seen in his Company.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: Well! the pimps in this Town are a Company of empty idle fellows, they have no design in 'em.

sp.speaker: La. Vain.
sp.p: Sir, I am sorry you are such a kind of Man, but—

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: Sorry! well! if I would bend my self to't I would starve all these Pimps, they should not eat bread, but I am not thought fit.

sp.speaker: La. Va.
sp.p: Sure you railly all this while.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: Railly! ha, ha, ha. Why there is not a Lady of Pleasure from Blackwall to Tuttle-Fields that I am not intimately acquainted with, nay that I do not know the state of her Body from her first Entring into the Calling.

sp.speaker: La. Vain.
sp.p: O Madam! I am undone, ruin'd for ever by being in his Company.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: Besides for debauching of Women, Madam, I am the greatest son of a Whore in the World if any one comes near me.

sp.speaker: La. Vain.
sp.p: Out upon you, if you be such a man I will have nothing to do with you, see me no more, I must look to my Honour, my Reputation is dearer to me then all the VVorld. I would not have a blemish in my Honour for all the riches of the Earth, this makes me so covetous of your Ladiships Company, a person of so much Vertue and Honour, but for Sir Positive I defye him; forbear my presence, you will undoe my Honour for ever.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: Oh what have I done?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: O horrid Impertinence!

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: Nay, nay, Dear Cozen stay, and see us friends first, Madam, I beg a thousand pardons: 'Tis true, I said no man in England understood pimping better then my self, but I meant the speculative not the practical part of pimping.

sp.speaker: La. Va.
sp.p: O that's something, I assure you, if you had not brought your self off well with your Speculation, I would never have suffer'd you to have Practis'd upon me, for no VVoman in England values her Honour more then I do.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: Oh Madam, we must go to the Setting Dog and Partridge to supper to night, Master Whiskin came to invite us, there will be the Blades, and we shall have a Ball.

sp.speaker: La. Vain.
sp.p: VVill there be none but our own Company?

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: No Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Va.
sp.p: VVell! I am resolv'd not to fail if I can by any means get rid of Sir Positive, for I love meat and drink and fidles, and such merry Gentlemen with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Your servant Dear Hearts; Madam, Emilia I kiss your hand: Dear Iack.

sp.speaker: Emilia.
sp.p: Nay, now it is time to shift for our selves.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: My Dear Bully-Rock can I serve thee in any thing?

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Nay, then fare you well.—

div.stage: Emil. and Stanf. run out at several doors, the Impertinents divided follow 'em.

div.head: ACT. III.
div.stage: Enter Stanford, Emilia, Sir Positive, Lady Vaine, Woodcock and Ninny.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: NAy then Cozen, I am an Ass, an Ideot, a Blockhead and a Rascal, if I don't understand Drammatique Poetry of all things in the World; why this is the onely thing I am esteem'd for in England.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: I can hold no longer. aside. This Rudeness of yours amazeth me; 'Tis beyond all Example, must we be perpetually persecuted by you and your Crew. For Heav'ns sake leave me.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha: Coz, thou railliest well; 'Tis true, Woodcock and Ninny will be a little troublesome sometimes; but 'ifaith they are very Honest fellows ' Give e'm their due.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Oh abominable! Worse and worse.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: to Ninny and Wood. Gentlemen! what Obligation have we to indure your folly any longer, must we be forc'd to leave the World for such importunate fools as you are?

sp.speaker: Ninny.
sp.p: What a Devil ayles he? he's mad; who does he mean by this?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Nay faith I don't know, I am sure he does not mean me, Dear Heart.

sp.speaker: Ninny.
sp.p: Nor me neither; Take that from me.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Iack if thou wilt leave the World, I'le go along with thee as I told thee, Dear Heart; but who is't troubles thee now Bully-Rock?

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: All of ye; ye are a pack of the most insupportable fools That e're had breath, I had rather be at a Bear-Garden Then be in your Company.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha: This is very pleasant ifaith: Call the greatest VVits and Authors of the Nation fools, Ha, ha, ha. That's good ifaith.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Nay, perhaps the greatest men of the Age: you are a great Judge indeed, &c.

sp.speaker: Lady Vaine.
sp.p: Nay Sir Positive e'en leave her (don't be troublesome) since she desires you: Come Madam, I'le wait upon you, whither you please: wee'l enjoy our selves in private.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: This is worst of all; Do you think I can suffer the Noyse of your Tongue forever with patience?

sp.speaker: La. Vain.
sp.p: O'my Conscience Sir Positive she's distracted.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: Yes Madam, if I be a judge she is, and I defie any one to deceive me in this.

sp.speaker: La. Vaine.
sp.p: It must be so, for she has a vast deal of wit, and great wits you know have always a Mixture of Madness.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: Well Madam! I found that by my self, for I was about three years ago as mad as ever man was; I 'scap'd Bedlam very narrowly, 'tis not above a twelve-moneth since my brains were settl'd again: But come, Madam, I'le wait on your Ladiship, for she do's not deserve the honour of such Company.

sp.speaker: La. Vain.
sp.p: What shall I do? to get rid of him, I shall miss my assignation, if I do not.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.l: Come, Madam—
Fare you well! since you are no better Company—

div.stage: Ex. Sir Pos. and La. Vain.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: So, so, now we shall be a little at rest: for let me tell you Madam, though Sir Positive be a rare man, yet my Lady Vaine is a little too talkative, and there can be no greater Trouble to one of sence then that.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: You are the most impertinent of all Mankind.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Oh Madam! you are pleas'd to say so—

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: You are a most abominable fool, and the worst Poet in Christendom: I had rather read the History of Tom Thumb then the best of your Poems.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Oh Madam! you are pleasant, but this won't pass,

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Such ridiculous insipid Rhimes are you Author of, That I am confident you are that incorrigible scribbler that furnishes the Bell-man of this Ward.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, &c. Madam: as I hope to breath you droll very well, this is the pretty'st humour in the World.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: O Heav'n! what will become of me?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Is not this extremely pleasant?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: There was never any thing equal to't.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Your Verses are such as School-boyes ought to be whipp'd for.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: This will not stir me; Madam, I know you are not in Earnest.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: And your Playes are below the Dignity of a Mountebanks stage. Salvator Winter wou'd have refus'd them.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Nay, Madam, never talk of that, I'le shew you a Play I have about me: Come, Madam, wee'l read it, here's the most glorious conceits, the most powerful touches, in a word, 'tis a Play that shall Read and Act with any Play that ever was born, I mean, conceived.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Come on Iack!

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Ah! Dear Lovell! use some means for my delivery, or I am ruin'd for ever: for if I shou'd go they wou'd not leave me, they are so barbarously cruel in their persecutions.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Nay, never speak of that Madam, before George you will bring your Judgement in question if you condemn Ninny's Playes Dear Heart.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Away you Coxcomb, you are ten times a more Ridiculous 'Squire then he's a Poet.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha. By the Lord Harry this is a strange humour of hers as ever I saw in my life: Well Madam you will have your frolick, but come Ninny, wee'l e'en take our leaves.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Ay, ay, come, your humble servants.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Your servant, Dear Hearts, this is the pleasant'st humor in the World.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Ay, is't not? ha, ha, ha—

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: O Friend, I have been more inhumanely us'd then ever Bawd was by the fury of the ' Prentices.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Still I say laugh at 'em as I do.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Let's leave 'em Lovell, for they are in such humours, they are onely fit for one anothers Company.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: With all my heart, Madam—

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Well! I will leave the World immediately.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Which way do you intend to go?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Why do you ask?

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: That I may be sure to take another way.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Nothing could so soon perswade me to tell you as that.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: What are they gone? they have lock'd the door too!

sp.speaker: Emil.
