sp.p: I wonder what they leave us alone for.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Heav'n knows, unless it be to be troublesome to one another as they have been to us.

div.stage: They walk up and down and take little notice of one another.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: I am sure I have most reason to fear it.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: You most reason? when did you see a man so foolish as a Woman?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: When I see you.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: No, no, none of our sex will dispute folly with yours.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: That's hard, I find nothing but Owls among the best of you; your young men are all positive, forward, conceited Coxcombs, and your old men all formall nothings, that wou'd have their sullen gravity mistaken for wisdom.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: This is not altogether so much Impertinence as I expected from one of your sex, but let me tell you, I have too often suffer'd by Women, not to fear the best of 'em, there being nothing to be found in most of the sex, but vanity, pride, envy and hypocrisie, uncertainty and giddiness of humour, the furious desires of the young make 'em fit to be seduc'd by the flesh, as the envy and malice of the old prepare 'em to be led away by the Devil.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: I must confess I don't perceive yet that you are altogether so ridiculous as the rest of Mankind, but let me tell you, I have Reason to fear you will be so, perhaps your impertinence is an Ague that haunts you by fits.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: That disease in the best of Women is quotidian, and if you be not infected, you must be the most Extraordinary Woman in the World.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p:
I would give Money to see a man that is not so as the Rabble do, to see a Monster since all men I have ever seen are
most intolerable Fops, would it not distract one to see Gentlemen of 5000 l. a year write Playes, and as Poets venture their Reputations against a sum of Money, they venture theirs against Nothing, others learn Ten years to play o' the Fiddle and to Paint, and at last an Ordinary Fiddler or Sign-Painter that makes it his bus'ness shall out-do 'em all.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: This looks like sence, I find she does understand something.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Others after twenty or thirty years study in Philosophy arrive no further then at the Weighing of Carps, the Invention of a travailling Wheel, or the poisoning a Cat with the oyle of Tobacco, these are your Wits and Vertuoso's.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: I must confess this is not so ill as I expected from you; but it do's not less distract me to see a young Lady fall in Love with a vain empty fellow not worth a Groat, perhaps for dancing of a Jigge, or singing of a Stanza of fashionable Non-sence, another on the contrary so insatiably covetous, for money, to marry old age, infirmity, and diseases, and the same bait that perswades 'em to Matrimony shall entice 'em into Adultery.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: This is not so foppish as I believ'd, yet though this be a great Truth, 'tis a very impertinent thing of you to tell me what I know already.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: How the Devil should I know that, I am sure not many of your sex are guilty of so much discretion as to discern these things.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: I am sure you have not much that cannot distinguish between those that have and have not.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: I must confess I am a little surpriz'd to find a Woman have so little vanity, I could never indure the Society of any of the sex better then yours.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: To be plain with you, you are not so troublesome ●●op as I have seen.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: What the Devil makes me think this Woman not impertinent? and yet I cannot help it, what an Owl am I?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: I have been so cruelly tormented, and without intermission too, that this seems some Refreshment to me.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p:
Why should I be catch'd thus, but I'le keep my folly to my self▪— aside.
I can bear this with a little more patience; but if you To her. should grow much Impertinent, I shou'd venture to break open the Doore for my Liberty, I can assure you.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Pray Heaven you don't give me the first occasion [to him. Well I know not what's the matter, but I like this man strangely; but, What a Fool am I?

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: How like a Woodcock am I insnar'd; a [To himself, to him▪ Curse on Lovel for leaving me alone with her.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: VVhat do they intend to keep us prisoners forever.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: I care not how long; [Aside. I think they intend to deal with us as they do with [To her. Juries, shut us up till we agree of our Verdict.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: That would be longer then the Seige of Troy 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: This is not half so bad though as our late persecutions, That's one Comfort.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: It fares with me like one upon a Rock, that is a little loossen'd from his paines; 'tis pleasure to him when he compares his torments, though those he has left may be intollerable too.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: In this we agree, though in nothing else.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: I wou'd to Heaven we did in all things; I am [Aside. tormented with my self, that am forc'd by the Ridiculous Custom of Women to dissemble, and that way indure my own foppery— Ah dear Stanford.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: How now! she smil'd, and suddenly check'd the Liberty she took.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: O Heaven! I fear he has discover'd something.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: There must be something in't, I like her very well, but am resolv'd not to disclose it what e're comes on't; for, that will make her vain, though she be not already.

sp.speaker: Emili.
sp.p: Why don't you break open the door, Sir,

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: I don't find much reason for't yet.

sp.speaker: Emili.
sp.p: I could find in my heart to give you enough.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Nay, I doubt not but 'tis in your Nature. What can the meaning of this be? Is there nothing but Riddle in Woman?

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Mr. Huffe: my Master charg'd me of all men living to keep you out of his sight.

div.stage: Enter Huffe and unlocks the door, and Roger after him, & lays hold on him.

sp.speaker: Huffe.
sp.p: Prethee stand by you sawcy Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, be not so boisterous; upon my word you pass no further.

sp.speaker: Huffe.
sp.p: Prethee (dear Roger) do'nt put this upon me.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: My Master sayes it costs him two pieces a time to be rid of you.

sp.speaker: Huffe.
sp.p: Prethee let me go, and you shall go my halfes.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Are you in earnest?

sp.speaker: Huffe.
sp.p: Yes upon my Honour.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Nay then speed yee, but be sure you sinke nothing.

sp.speaker: Huffe.
sp.p: I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Is he here! hold, hold, hold, here's your two peices, don't trouble me now.

sp.speaker: Huffe.
sp.p: Your humble Servant, I'le returne e'm again to morrow without faile: Ha! Do they come so easily; there are more from whence these came: O Sir, I'le tell you, I have had the severest fortune that ever man had.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Away, away.

sp.speaker: Huffe.
sp.p: For Heaven's sake hear, it's the most prodigious thing you ever heard.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: What will this World come to?

sp.speaker: Huffe.
sp.p: I was playing at Back-Gammon for my Dinner, which I won; and from thence we came to five up for half a piece; of the first set I had three for love and lost it▪ of the second I Gammon'd him, and threw Doublets at last, which you know made four, and lost that too; of the third I won never a Game.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: O Devil! Is this the Miraculous thing you would tell me, Fare-well.

sp.speaker: Huffe.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Sir! you don't hear the end on't.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Nor do I desire it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Huffe.
sp.p: I'le tell you, Sir, of the fourth set I was four to two, and for the last game my Tables were fill'd up, and I had born my three odd men, so that you know I had two upon every point.

sp.speaker: Emili.
sp.p: O insufferable! though I feel enough my self, yet I cannot but pitty Stanford.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: O Damn'd Impertinence! Sir, I tell you, I don't understand Back-Gamon.

sp.speaker: Huffe.
sp.p: Not understand Back-Gamon: Sir, that you may understand well what I say, I'le tell you what Back-Gamon is.

sp.speaker: Emili.
sp.p: This is worse then t'other: sure Stanford has some Charme about him, that I can suffer this rather then leave him.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: I desire none of your Instructions.

sp.speaker: Huffe.
sp.p: Well: then as I was a saying, I had just two upon every point, and he had two Men to enter; and as the Devil wou'd have it, my next throw was Size-Ace; he enter'd one of his Men a Size; then Mr. Stanford, to see the Damn'd luck on't, I threw Size-Sinke next, and the very next throw he enter'd upon a Sink, and having his Game very backward, won the Game, and afterwards he Set so, that I lost every penny.

sp.speaker: Stanford.
sp.p: This will distract me; VVhat the Devill's this to me?

sp.speaker: Huffe.
sp.p: No: but did you ever hear the like in your life?

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: This puts me beyond all patience.

sp.speaker: Huffe.
sp.p: But this was not all; for just in the Nick came she that Nurs'd my three last Children that were born without Wedlock, and threaten'd to turn e'm upon my hands if I did not pay her.— 'Faith Mr. Stanford three Pieces more will do my business; upon my Honour I'le pay you to morrow: Come will you Communicate?

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Yes that, that's fitter for you—

sp.speaker: Huffe.
sp.p: VVhat is that Dear Heart?

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: 'Tis that Sir▪—

sp.speaker: Huffe.
sp.p: That Sir, I don't understand you; if you go to that Sir: There's a business indeed. VVhat do you mean by this? VVhat would you make a quarrel, Sir? You'l never leave those tricks: I have told you of e'm often enough. What the Devil do you mean by that?

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Let this expound my meaning.—

sp.speaker: Huffe.
sp.p:
'Slife, Sir, I don't understand you: and ye talk of these things, and these businesses, Sir, I'de have you know, I scorn to
be kick'd as much as any man breathing, Sir; and you be that Sport, your Servant, your Servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Come Mr. Huffe, Divide.

sp.speaker: Huffe.
sp.p: Divide! There's one for you, for two of e'm was all I got.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: This you might have kept to your self if you had pleas'd, but, D'ye think I'le be serv'd thus?

sp.speaker: Huffe.
sp.p: Let me go.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: I'le not leave you so.—

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Why do'nt you go? the Doores open now, Sir.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: I am affraid I shall light into worse Company.

sp.speaker: Emili.
sp.p: O Sir, that's impossible!

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: How vain this is of you; now would you give me a fair occasion to flatter you, but I can assure you, you shall miss of your design.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Well, this is an extraordinary man; I love the [Aside. very sight of him: I wonder, Sir, you'l be so foppish to [To him. imagine I love to be flatter'd; I hate flatterers worse then our new Poets

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: What an Owle am I to like this Woman! sure I am bewitch'd.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Aside. Well, Sir, Farewell: and yet I would not leave him.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: You'd e'n as good stay, Madam, while you are well: you may perhaps if you go, incounter some of your Persecutors.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: I'de rather stay here then venture that; my trouble is not here so insupportable.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: She must be a rare Woman! [Aside. Nor perhaps is not like to be, unless it comes from your [To her. self▪ But I think there's less vanity in you then in most women I have seen.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: This is a most excellent person.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p:
Dear Emilia. [Aside.
O Heaven! Is he here?

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: Iack; Hark ye.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: For Heaven's sake! I have business.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: 'Tis all one for that, Sir; Why I'le tell you.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Another time; I beseech you don't interrupt me now.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: 'Faith but I must interrupt you.

sp.speaker: Emilia.
sp.p: What can be the matter he listens to him.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: 'Slife, Why should you put this upon me now.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: If you refuse me, I'le blast your Reputation.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: What shall I do? though this be a Coxcombly-Knight, yet the Puppies stout; are you so cunning in [To him. persecuting me, to put a thing upon me I cannot refuse: well Sir, remember this.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: What can this mean?

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Come, Sir, I'le follow you, but a Curse upon you for finding me out: Madam, assoon as I have dispatch'd this business, 'tis possible I may see you agen.

sp.speaker: Emili.
sp.p: But 'tis not, I'le assure you; I'le never see the Face of one, that has so little sence to be seduc'd by such an Ideot as that is.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: How ridiculous is this of you, to Judge of a thing before you know the Bottom on't.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: Come, Stanford, 'prethee come away

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Have I found you? this Fellows as bad as any, and without doubt did but Counterfeit his humour, to insinuate himself into my good opinion. What lucky Accident is this has undeceiv'd me? I felt a passion growing in me might else have prov'd dangerous— Luce—

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Fetch my Hoods and Scarfes, I'le take a walk in the Fields.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: How Sister! What have you lost your Gallant:

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: O Sister, I thank you for locking me up with that Fellow; well, the time may come when I may be quit with you.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p:
I wonder how the Door came open; I believe there
has been hard bickering betwixt e'm: but, I find my Sister is Conqueror, and your Friend is fled for the same.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Fare well he, let us mind our selves. Come, 'Faith Madam, Why should you and I hover so long about this Matrimony; Like a Cast of Faulcons about a Hern that dare not stoop.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: O Sir, the Quarry does not Countervaile the Danger.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I'le warrant you, Madam; but let's railly no longer, there is a Parson at Knights-bridge that yoakes all stray People together, we'll to him, he'l dispatch us presently, and send us away as lovingly as any two Fooles that ever yet were condemn'd to Marriage.

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.p: I should be inclinable enough to cast my self upon you; but I am affraid you are gone so far with my Lady Vaine, you can never come off with Honour: Besides, I am sure, what e're you say, you cannot so soon forget your kindness to her; and if after we are yoak'd, as you call it, you should draw that way, I should draw another; and then our Yoak would go neer to Throttle us.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Faith some would think it much the easier if 'twere wide enough to draw both wayes: But Madam, Will you never be serious with me?

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: I know you cannot love me, she's your delight.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I delight in her as I do in the Tooch-Ache; I love her immoderately, as an English Taylor loves a French Taylor that's set up the next door to him.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: Sir, to keep you no longer in suspence, I am resolv'd never to Marry without my Fathers Consent.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Madam, I'le not despair of obtaining that.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: He has Vow'd never to Marry me till he has dispos'd of my Elder Sister.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Will you assure me to make me happy when that's done?

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: I think I may safely promise any thing against that time; for, as long as my Sister has these Mellanchollick-Humors, she's far enough from that danger.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I'le warrant you I'le make a Match yet between Stanford and her.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: That's impossible, unless you can alter their Natures▪ for though neither finds Impertinence in themselves, they I find it in one another: besides, their very Principles are against all Society.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Well, Madam, I have a way to make e'm stark mad in love with one another; or at least fetch e'm out of their Sullenness: We will perpetually bait e'm with our Fooles, and by that we shall either plague e'm out of their humour, or at least make their fellow-sufferings be a meanes to endeare e'm one to another.

div.stage: Enter Sir Positive, Standford, and two Clerks.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: Now will I firke my two Clerks.

sp.speaker: 2 Clerk.
sp.p: But, Sir, before we engage, I would satisfie my Conscience whether the Cause be just or no?

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Hang the Cause, we come to fight.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: Why, I'le tell you the Cause, Sir.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: By no meanes, Sir Positive, we come to fight here, not to tell stories.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: Wee'l fight too; but by your leave I'le tell the Cause first, and you were my Father.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, think upon your Honour, this is no place for Words; Let your Sword speak your Mind.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: Sir, by your Pardon, I am resolv'd to satisfie e'm; no man in England knows how to manage these things better then my self, take that from me.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: O horrid Impertinence, I fear these Fooles Tongues more then I can their Swords.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p:
Sir, no man in England would put up this affront; Why look you, Sir, for him to sit in the Eighteen Pence Gallery, pray mark me, and rail at my Play alowd the first day, and did all that lay in his power to damn it: And let me tell you, Sir, if in any Drammatick Poem there has been such breaks, such Characters, such Figures, such Images, such Heroick Patterns, such Heights,
such Flights, such Intrigues, such Surprizes, such Fire, Salt, and Flame, then I am no Judge: I understand nothing in this World.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: What a Cause his Valour has found out; and how he Cants too; What an Owle was I to come along with him; Sir Positive dispatch. Come, come, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: Hold a little—

sp.speaker: 2 Clerk.
sp.p: VVhy look you Mr. Timothy, this is a very honest and in enious Gentleman for ought I see.

sp.speaker: 1 Clerk.
sp.p: 'Tis true, I sate in the Eighteen Pence Gallery, but I was so far from Railling against your Play, that I cry'd it up as high as I could.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: How high did you cry it up?

sp.speaker: 1 Clark.
sp.p: Why as high as the upper Gallery, I am sure of that.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: O Cowardly Currs! Will they never fight: Y'e ly, y'e did Rail at his Play.

sp.speaker: 1 Clerk.
sp.p: Sir, I'le hold you twenty pound I don't lie; Sir, Were you there? Did you hear me? This is the strangest thing in the World.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Will nothing make these Rogues fight? You are both Rascally Cowards.

sp.speaker: 2 Clerk.
sp.p: 'Tis strange you should say so, you are very uncharitable; Do you know either of us?

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Oh insufferable! What Sons of VVhores has he pick'd up, and what an occasion too?

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: VVhy do you say, you did not Raile; Did not I sit just under you in the Pit?

sp.speaker: 2 Clerk.
sp.p: Lord! VVho would expect to see a Poet in the Pitt at his own Play?

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: Did not you say, Fy upon't, that shall not pass!

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Gentlemen! either Fight quickly.—

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: Hold hold, let him speak; VVhat can you say? Do Gentlemen VVrite to oblige the VVorld, and do such as you traduce e'm— ha—

sp.speaker: 1 Clerk.
sp.p:
Sir, I'le tell you, you had made a Lady in your Play so unkind to her Lover (who methought was a very honest well-meaning-Gentleman) to command him to hang himself;
Said I then that shall not pass, thinking indeed the Gentleman would not have done it, but he indeed did it, then said I fy upon't that he should be so much over-taken.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: Overtaken! that's good 'ifaith, why you had as good call the Gentleman fool: and 'tis the best Character in all my Play. De'think I'le put that up.

sp.speaker: 1 Clerk.
sp.p: Not I Sir as I hope to live; I would not call the Gentleman Fool for all the World, but 'tis strange a man must pay eighteen pence, and must not speak a word for't.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: Not when Gentlemen write; take that from me.

sp.speaker: 2 Clerk.
sp.p: No, I would they would let it alone then.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: But Stanford it would make an Authour mad to see the Invincible Ignorance of this age, now for him to hang himself at the Command of his Mistress there's the surprize, and I'le be content to hang my self, if ever that was shewn upon a stage before, besides 'twas an Heroick Cato-like Action, and there's great Love and Honour to be shewn in a mans hanging himself for his Mistress, take that from me.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: O horrid! this Magisterial Coxcomb will defend any thing.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: What do you think Stanford, you are a great Judge?

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: I think a Halter is not so honourable as a Ponyard, and therefore not so fit to express Love and Honour with.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha To see your mistake now that's the onely thing in the Play I took pains for, I could have made it otherwise with ease, but I will give you seventeen reasons why a Halter's better then a Ponyard. First, I'le show you the posture of hanging, look, d'ye mind me, it is the posture of a Pensive dejected Lover with his hands before him, and his head aside thus.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: I would you had a Halter you would demonstrate it more cleerly.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: 'Faith, and would I had, I'de show it you to the life— but secondly—

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Hold Sir— I am convinced, to our fighting bus'ness agen; but they have given you full satisfaction,
Let's away—

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: No, no, hold a little.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: A Curse on him! did I leave Emilia for this?

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: Sir, if you'l see your hand to this Certificate 〈◊〉 satisfy'd, otherwise you must take what follows.

sp.speaker: 1 Clerk.
sp.p: Sir! with all my heart, I'le do any thing to serve you.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: I had this ready on purpose, for I was resolv'd if we had fought, and I had disarm'd him, I'de have made him do't before I'de have given him his life, how do you write your self?

sp.speaker: 1 Clerk.
sp.p: Timothy Scribble a Justice of Peace his Clerk.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: Here read it, and set your hand to it.

sp.speaker: 1 Clerk
sp.p: reads I do acknowledge and firmly believe that the play of Sir Positive Att-all Knight, call'd the Lady in the Lobster, notwithstanding it was damn'd by the Malice of the Age, shall not onely read, but it shall Act with any of Ben. Iohnsons and Beaumont's and Fletcher's Plays.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: Hold, hold! I'le have Shakespeares in, 'slife I had like to have forgot that.

sp.speaker: 1 Clerk
sp.l: reads With all my heart.
sp.p: I do likewise hereby attest that he is no Purloiner of other mens Works, the general fame and opinion notwithstanding, and that he is a Poet, Mathematician, Divine, Statesman, Lawyer, Physitian, Geographer, Musitian, and indeed a Unus in Omnibus through all Arts and Sciences, and hereunto I have set my hand the day of

sp.speaker: 1 Clerk▪
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: Come Sir, do you Witness it.

sp.speaker: 2 Clerk.
sp.p: Ay Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: In presence of Iacob Dash.

sp.speaker: 1 Clerk.
sp.p: Look you Sir I write an indifferent good hand, if you have any occasion to command me, inquire at the Stationers at Furnivals Inne.—

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Why you Impudent Rascals! how dare you; offers to come into the Field? must I be diverted thus long by kick 'em. you?

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: Hold Stafford! I cannot in honour suffer that now they are my Friends, and after this satisfaction I am bound in honour to defend 'em to the last drop of blood.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: O intolerable!

sp.speaker: 1 Clerk.
sp.p:
Sir! I pray be not angry! we did not come into the
〈◊〉 to fight, but Master Dash and I came to play a match at Trap-ball for a Dish of Steakes at Gloster-hall, and here you found us.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: Have you the Confidence to talk of Trap-ball before me, nay, now you are my Enemies agen: hark you Stanford I'le play with 'em both for 5 cool. why I was so eminent at it when I was a School-boy, that I was call'd Trap Positive all over the School.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Then farewel good Sir Positive Trap.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: Dear Stanford stay but one quarter of an hour, and you shall see how I'le dishonour 'em both at Trap-ball— They talk of Trap-ball, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Slife what will become of me: out of the field you inconsiderable Rascals. Must I be diverted thus by you—

div.stage: Enter Emilia and her Maid at one Door, Ninny and Woodcock at t'other.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: I thought we might have been free here: and here are these Puppy's.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Let's aboard of 'em, who e're they are, fa, la, la, how now Dear Hearts? by the L. Harry its pity you should walk without a Couple of Servants, here's a Couple of Bully-Rocks will serve your turn, as well as Two of Buckram, Dear Hearts.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: O Heaven!—

sp.speaker: Lice.
sp.p: Gentlemen this is very rude! we shall have them come shall thank you for't.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: As I hope to breath Ladies you look the pretty'st in Vizard Masks of any Ladies in England.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: And now you talk of Masks, I'le show you an admirable Song upon a Vizard Mask, Dear Hearts, of Poet Ninny's making.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Oh abominable Impudence!

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: But I must beg your pardon that I cannot sing it, for I am hoarse already with singing it to the Maids of Honour.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: You sing it to the Maids of Honour?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: But if I had a Violin here, no man in England can express any thing more lusciously upon that then my self, ask Ninny else.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Yes Ladies! he has great power upon the Violin, he has the best double Rellish in Gam-ut of any man in England, but for the little finger on the left hand no man in Europe out-does him.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: You may believe him, Dear Hearts, for he's a great Judge of Musick, and as pretty a Poet as ever writ Couplet.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: O horrid! what's this? there's no way to scape, but to discover our selves.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Emilia! what shall I do? I am undone, shee'l never own me agen.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Farewel you Baboons, and learn better manners.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: 'Slife shee'l take me for a Whore-master, I am nipt in the very blossome of my hopes.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: For Heav'ns sake, pardon me Madam.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Let me go.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: No Madam, wee'l wait on your Ladiship home.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: This is worse and worse.

sp.speaker: Huff.
sp.p: Heart! if I put up this, I'le give him leave to use me worse then a Bayley that arrests in the Inns of Court.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Why! what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Huff.
sp.p: 'Slife kick a man of honour as I am, I'le pistoll him pissing against a Wall.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Ay then or never to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: What's the bus'ness Dear Heart, hah?

sp.speaker: Huff.
sp.p: Sir, I'le tell you.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: This is a lucky Occasion.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Are you gone, I'le follow you.

sp.speaker: Huff.
sp.p: I had occasion for four or five Pieces to make up a Sum with, and went to borrow it of him, and he like an uncivil fellow as he was—

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: What did he?

sp.speaker: Huff.
sp.p: Why I did but turn my back, and he like an ill-bred sot, gives me a kick or two of the breech, I'le cut his throat if I should meet him in a Church.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: This will be an ill bus'ness; I am sorry for my Friend Iack Stanford.— for Master Huffes honour aside, is disturb'd and I fear hee'l revenge it bloodily, for he understands Punctilio's to a hair, but I'le endeavour to prevent it however.

sp.speaker: Huff.
sp.p: If he be above ground I'le cutt's throat for't, I'le teach him to use a man of honour thus, if he had pleas'd he might have dealt with me at another rate, as I hope to live I had a fighting Sword by my side neer six foot long at that very time, and he to kick a man, P'shaw He does not understand his bus'ness, but I shall find him presently.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Pox on't Woodcock she would not let me go with her.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Prethee, Dear Heart, see if thou canst find Jack Stanford in the Fields, while I go and feel if I can find him in the Town.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: 'Tis a business concerns his life, Dear Heart, ask no questions, but if you find him, bring him to the Sun.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: What can this be?

div.l: But I'le go see if I can find him out,
So to be sure of what I ' me now in doubt▪

div.head: Act. IV.

sp.speaker: La. Va.
sp.p: COme Madam, I am not so blind, but I have discover'd something.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What have you discover'd Madam?

sp.speaker: La. Va.
sp.p: Let me tell you, Madam, 'tis not for your honour to give meetings privately to Master Lovell.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Why Madam, if I shou'd, are you concern'd in it?

sp.speaker: La. Vain.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, first in my good Wishes to your Ladiship, I would not have the World blame your Conduct, not that you shou'd have the least blemish in your honour, but that your Fame and Vertue shou'd continue unspotted and undefil'd as your Ladiships Beauty is.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Fear not, Madam, I'le warrant you I'le secure my honour without your Instructions.

div.stage: Enter Lovell softly, and comes just behind them.

sp.speaker: La. Vain.
sp.p: But, Madam, let me tell you agen, no Woman has really that right in Master Lovell that I have: but he's false Wretch Madam, he has no Religion in him, if he had any Conscience, or had used to have heard Sermons, he would never have been so wicked and perfidious to a poor Innocent Woman as I am.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: This is very fine i'faith—

sp.speaker: La. Vain.
sp.p: Madam, he protested all the honourable kindness in the World to me, and has receiv'd Favours from me, I shall not mention at this time, and now he has rais'd the siege from before me, and laid it to your Ladiship.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I cannot imagine what you mean by this?

sp.speaker: La. Va.
sp.p: And Madam to confess my Weakness to you, I must needs say, I love him of all men in the World.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Well, Madam, since you do, I'le resigne my Interest in the Gentleman you speak of, here he is.

sp.speaker: La. Va.
sp.p: Oh Heaven! am I betray'd? well, Madam, I shall acquaint your father with your Amour.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Hold, Madam, if you do perhaps I may whisper something in Sir Positive's ear.

sp.speaker: La. Vain.
sp.p: Sir! you will not be so ungenerous to boast of a Ladies kindness: if he shou'd say the least thing in the World after my unhansome leaving of him just now, it wou'd incense him past reconciliation, what a confusion am I in?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Is not this very pleasant Madam?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I wonder, Sir, after what has now past you have the confidence to look me in the face.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I like this raillery very well, Madam.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I can assure you, you shall have no reason to think I railly with you.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Certainly you cannot be in Earnest.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Upon my word you shall find I am, I will have nothing to do with any man that's engag'd already.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: You amaze me, Madam.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: 'Ile never see you more—

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: O friend! I'm glad I've found you.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I shall have no opportunity to appease my Mistress▪ if I do not get rid of him, but I have a trick for him.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Wou'd this woman were away, that I might acquaint you with the greatest concernment I ever had.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Step into that Chamber quickly, and I'le get rid of her, and come to you.—

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: With all my heart—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Certainly, Madam, you cannot know this Woman so little as to give her Credit? I'le tell you what she is.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I am very glad I know you so well: do you think I'le be put off with a Remnant of your Love?

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: O! Master Lovell! is my Master here? I have lost him these two houres.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Ay, ay, but Madam, for Heav'ns sake hear me!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Trouble me no more.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Where is this Master of mine: I have been seeking him these two hours, and cannot light of him.

sp.speaker: Huff.
sp.p: Oh Roger! where's your Master?

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: O Sir! you shall excuse me for that.

sp.speaker: Huff.
sp.p: Prethee dear Rogue tell me, 'twill be better for thee.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: No, no, that won't do, you were not so just to me last time.

sp.speaker: Huff.
sp.p: Upon my honour I was: Why shou'dst thou distrust thy friend?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Come Sir, don't think to Wheadle me at this rate!

sp.speaker: Huff.
sp.p: I am a son of a Whore if I was not just to you: but prethee bring me to him once more: I am sure to get money of him, and may I perish if I do not give you your share to a farthing.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Well! I'le trust you once more: go, and stay for me in the Hall, and I'le come to you when I have found my Master, who is somewhere in this house.

sp.speaker: Huff.
sp.p: Well! I'le wait for you—

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: My comfort is, if he gets money I may have my share, if not he ventures a kicking agen, and I venture nothing.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Oh Sir! I have been seeking you these two houres, and here's Master Lovell in the house.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: You Rascal, must you trouble me too?—

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: He does not trouble you more then you do me.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Now are you like a young hound that runs away with a false scent.

sp.speaker: Emili.
sp.p: For Heaven's sake leave me.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Nay! This is like a Woman, to condemn a man unheard.

sp.speaker: Emili.
sp.p: Must I be for ever pester'd with Impertinent people?

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: If you were not so your self, you wou'd not think me so; but she that has the Yellow Jaundies thinks every thing yellow which she sees.

sp.speaker: Emili.
sp.p: Is it possible you can have the impudence to endeavour to justifie your folly.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Not that I care much for satisfying you, but to vindicate myself from the unjust aspersion: know it was my honour oblig'd ' me to go along with that Foole.

sp.speaker: Emili.
sp.p: Out of my sight; Are you one of those Fopps that talk of honour?

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Is that a thing so despicable with you? he ask'd me to be his second, which I cou'd not in honour refuse.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Granting that barbarous custome of Duells; Can any thing be so ridiculous, as to venture your life for another mans quarrel, right or wrong?

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: I like this Woman more and more, like a sott as I am▪ sure there is VVitch-craft in't.—

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: But to do the greatest Act of Friendship in the World for the greatest Owle in Nature.

sp.speaker: Huffe.
sp.p: Oh Mr▪ Stanford, I have a business to impart to you.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: O insufferable! Have you the Impudence to trouble me agen.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: I know not what's the matter, but I cannot but have some inclination to this fellow yet.

sp.speaker: Huffe.
sp.p:
I am going into the City, where I shall have the rarest Bubble that ever man had; he was set me by a Renegado-Linnen-Draper, that fail'd last year in his Credit, and has now no other trade but to start the Game, whil'st we pursue the Chace. This is one of these fellowes that draw in the Youth of the City
into our Decoy, and perpetually walk up and down seeking for Prey.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Be gone! and leave me.

sp.speaker: Huffe.
sp.p: But you know a man must have a little Gold to show, to baite the Rogues withall.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Out, you unseasonable Rascal, Ile send you hence.

sp.speaker: Huffe.
sp.p: Nay, 'tis not that Sir can fright me, but that I would not disturb the Lady, I'de make you know.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: You impudent Villain, I'le send you further.

div.stage: Follows Huffe, and runs away huffing.

sp.speaker: Huffe.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, your humble Servant and you go to that, Sir; I care as little for a Sword, Sir, as any man upon Earth: I fear your Sword? Who dares say it? your Servant, your Servant.—

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: This is not altogether so foolish as fighting in Sir Positive's Quarrel.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Sir Positives quarrel! 'twas in effect my own; for I was sure to meet with some impertinent Fellow or other for my Enemy, and was glad of this opportunity to vent my indignation upon one of those many that have tormented me; I had rather fight with them all, then converse with them.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: But you may chuse whether you will do either.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Yes, as much as chuse whether I'le breathe or no.

sp.speaker: Emili.
sp.p: But how could you be sure to meet with such an one.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: VVhat Question is that? Is it not above 5000 to one odds?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: aside. I am glad he has brought himself well off, for I must like him, do what I can, he must be a man of sence▪ I must confess, the business is not altogether so ill as I imagin'd.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Now Madam, who is impertinent, you or I?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: You are to say the same thing twice to me.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: VVell! this is a rare VVoman: what a quick apprehension she has. I love her strangely, the more Coxcombe I, that I shou'd be drawn in of all men living.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: O Dear heart, have I met with thee; I have been seeking thee all the Town over.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Heart, What's this? I was going in great haste just as you came, adieu.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Ah dear Jack, I have not so little honour as to leave thee in this condition.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Good Sir! What condition? I am not Drunk, am I?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: No, Ga'd, wou'd it were no worse, Dear heart.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: It cannot be worse, do not trouble me.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: No, I'le tell thee Iack; Huffe threatens Embraces and kisses him. thee to cut thy Throat where ever he meets thee; and I came my Dear Bully-Rock to offer thee the Service of my sword and arme.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: For Heaven's sake put not this upon me; Do you think he that wou'd be kick'd without resistance, dares do any thing?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: But look you, Dear Heart, Lord this is the strangest thing in the World, you had Ladies with you, and you know it had been an uncivil thing to have turn'd agen then Iack: but now he's resolv'd to have satisfaction, he told me so; And if I can see as farr into a Millstone as another, he's no Bully Sandy.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Trouble me no more: be gone—

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Ay, ay, thou dost this now to try whether I have so little honour as to quit thee, but it won't pass, my dear Rascall; kiss me, I'le live and dye with thee.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Sir, let me tell you, this is very rude: and upon my word I have no quarrel unless you'l force one upon me.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Still do I like this man better and better.—

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Nay, then I smell a Rat— Farewell Iack— Servant, Dear Hearts.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: But, are you sure my Lady Vaine is such a one.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Yes, that I am, my little peevish Jealous Mistress.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I have reason to be jealous of such a Treasure as you are: But pray, to satisfie a little scruple I have, see her no more.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: We had best change the Scene, I think, what if you shou'd walk out a little.

sp.speaker: Emili.
sp.p: I care not much if I doe.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: I cou'd find in my heart to go along with you.

sp.speaker: Emili.
sp.p: Yes, and leave me agen for your Honour forsooth.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: How Devillishly impertinent is this for you to harp upon one string still.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Let's pursue our design.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: Agreed: and to our wish here comes my Cozin Positive.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: Oh! Have I found you: I'le tell you the pleasant'st thing in the World.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Sir, I am just now going to a Lawyer of the Temple to aske his Councell.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: P'shaw, p'shaw; save thy Money, what need'st thou do that, I'le do't for you; why I have more Law, then ever Cooke upon Littleton had; you must know, I am so eminent at that, that the greatest Lawyers in England come to me for advice in matters of difficulty: Come, state your Case, let's hear't, Come.— Hold, hold Cozen, Whither Emilia offers to go out. are you going.

sp.speaker: Emili.
sp.p: Let me goe, I am going in haste to bespeak a Seale.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p:
A Seale; Why do'st thou know what thou do'st now? To go about that without my advice: Well, I have given Symons and all of e'm such Lessons, as I have made e'm stand in admiration of my Judgment: Do you know
that I'le cut a Seale with any man in England for a thousand Pound.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: I have my Lesson, I'le warrant you I'le do't.

sp.speaker: Emili.
sp.l: O Heav'n!
sp.p: I must go now to bespeak it; I am to send it immediately to my Sister at the English Nunnery in Bruges.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: Bruges! ah dear Bruges; now you talk of Bruges, I am writing this night to Castel Rodrigo, you must know I have thought of their Affaires, and consider'd e'm thoroughly; and just this very After-noon I have found out such a way for e'm to preserve Flanders from the French, I defie all Mankind for such an Invention; and I think I offer him very fair, if he will let me divide the Government with him, I'le do't; otherwise if Flanders be lost, 'tis none of my fault.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: What is your Design Sir Positive?

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: That thou shoud'st be so very foppish to aske questions?

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: I'le tell you, I will this year; pray mark me, I will bring 100000 Men into the Field, d'ye see.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: But, Where will you have these Men, Cozen?

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: Have e'm P'shaw, p'shaw, let me alone for that; I tell thee Stanford, I will bring 100000 men into the Field, 60000 in one Compleat body, and 40000 for a flying Army, with which I will enter into the very Body of all France.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: O Devil! I had rather Flanders shou'd be lost, then hear any more on't.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: But this would signifie nothing, unless it were done by one that understands the conduct of an Army, which if I do not, let the World Judge: but to satisfie you, I'le tell you what I'le do, pray mark me, I will take threescore thousand Spanish Souldiers, and fight with 60000 French, and cut e'm off every Man: pray observe one, this is demonstration; then will I take those very numericall Individual Frenchmen I spoke of.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: What, after you have cut e'm off every man.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p:
Pish; What doest talk Man? What's matter whether it be before or after, that's not to the point? P'shaw, prethee don't thee trouble thy self for that, I'le do't man; I will take those very 60000 French and fight with a Spanish Army of
100000, and by my extraordinary Conduct destroy e'm all, this is demonstration, nothing can be plainer then this; by this you may guess whether I may not be a considerable Man to that Nation or no.— Nay, more then that, I'le undertake if I were in Candia, the Grand Visier would sooner expose himself to the fury of the Ianizaries, then besiege the Town while I were in't.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: I cannot tell whether I am more tormented with Sir Positive, or pleas'd with Stanford, he is an extraordinary man.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: But as I was saying, Cozen Emilia; I will have 100000 men in the Field, and I will man the Garrisons to the full: besides pray observe, I will have an infinite store of Provision every where, and pay all my Souldiers to a penny duly.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: But where's the Money to do this Cozen?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: What shall I do? Whether shall I turn me?

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Ah Dear Emilia!

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: VVhere's the Money, that's good one ' Faith!— Prethee dear Cozen do thou mind thy Guittar; thou dost not understand these things.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: I am sure I understand you to be the greatest Coxcomb in Nature.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: Then I will make you me a League Offensive and Defensive with the King of England, the Emperor and Princes of Germany, the King's of Sweden and Denmarke, the Kings of Portugal and Poland, Prester Iohn, and the Great Cham, the States of Holland, the Grand Duke of Muscovy, the Great Turk, with two or three Christian Princes more, that shall be nameless; and if with that Army, Provision and Alliance, I do not do the business, I am no Judge, I understand nothing in the VVorld.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: O Sir Positive! my Lady Vaine wou'd speak with you at your Lodging immediately.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: Cods my life-kins, Stanford, I am heartily sorry I must leave you.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: So am not I.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: I beg your pardon a thousand times. I vow●t Gad I wou'd not leave you but upon this occasion.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: How glad am I of the occasion!

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: going, returnes in haste. Well! I hope you'l be so kind to believe, that nothing but my Duty to my Mistress shou'd have made me part with you thus rudely.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: O yes! we do believe it.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: But hark you Cozen, and Stanford, you must promise me not to take it ill, as I hope to breathe I mean no incivility in the World.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Oh no, no, by no meanes.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: Your Servant.—

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: Come, Lovel, let's follow him, and either prepare him, or find out some others for a fresh incounter.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Allon's, but be sure, Roger, you forget not what I said to you.—

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: I will not, Sir.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: How Curteously he excus'd himself, for not tormenting us more.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: This is the first good turne my Lady Vaine e're did me.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: No, Madam, this was my ingenuity; I ne'r saw my Lady Vaine, not do I know where she is.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: Cozen and Mr. Stanford, I have consider'd on't, and I vow to Gad I am so affraid you'l take it ill, that rather then disoblige you, I'le put it off.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: O no Sir, by no meanes; 'twould be the rudest thing in the World to disobey your Mistress.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: Nay, 'Faith I see thou art angry now, 'prethee don't trouble thy selfe, I'le stay with thee.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Hell and Damnation! this is beyond all sufferance.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Let me advise you by all meanes to go to your Mistress.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: Well! if you won't take it ill, I'le go; adieu.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: That's he, seize him.

sp.speaker: Serje.
sp.p: Sir, by your leave, you must go to the Captain of the Guard.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: O! intollerable! What's the matter now?

sp.speaker: Serjaent.
sp.p: I do not know, but I guess 'tis upon a quarrel betwixt you and one Lieutenant Huffe.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Was ever any thing so unfortunate as this? Can't you defer't an houre?

sp.speaker: Serje.
sp.p: I am commanded by my Officer and dare not disobey.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: How loath am I to leave this Woman; there is something extraordinary in this— Madam; I am willing enough to stay with you, but you see I am forc'd away:— stay you here Roger.—

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: VVhat an unlucky accident is this? but my misfortunes never faile me.—

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: So, he's safe, and I have done what I in honour ought to do; and now honest Roger, my dear Bully-Rock, I'le stay with thee, prethee kiss me, thou art the honestest Fellow in the World.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Sir, I am glad I can Repay your Commendations; I have the best newes for y'e that ever you heard in your life.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Me! VVhat is't Dear Heart?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: VVhy, I'le tell you, the Lady Emilia is in love with you.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: In love with me, fy, fy, Pox on't what a VVheadling Rogue art thou now? VVhy should'st thou put this upon thy Friend now?

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Sir, this suspition of yours is very injurious: Let me tell you, that I am sure I have not deserv'd it from you Sir.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Nay, I must confess, I have alwayes found thee an honest Fellow, Dear Heart; but a Pox on't, she can't love me: P'shaw, me? VVhat, what can she see in me to love me for? no, no.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Sir! upon my life, it's true.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: Ha, ha, Dear Rascal, kiss me, the truth on't is, I have thought some such thing a pretty while, but how the Devil com'st thou to find it out, on my Conscience thou art a Witch.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: O Sir! I am great with her Maid Luce, and she told me her Lady fell in love with you for singing, she says you have the sweetest Voice, and the delicatest Method in singing of any man in England.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: As Gad shall sa'me, she is a very ingenious Woman; Dear Dog, Honest Rascal here, here's for thy Newes, I'le go in and give her a song immediately—

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: How greedily he swallows the bait: but ' these self-conceited Ideots can never know when they are wheadl'd.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: P'shaw, p'shaw, ad'au'tre, ad'au'tre, I can't abide you shou'd put your tricks upon me.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Come, Ninny, leave Fooling, you know I scorn it, I have always dealt faithfull with you.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: aside. I must confess he has always commended my Poems, that's the truth on't: But I am affraid this is impossible, don't Wheadle your friend.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: I shall be angry Sir, if you distrust me longer.
You may neglect this opportunity of raising your self,
Do, but perhaps you may never have such another.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: Nay▪ but dear Sir, speak! are you in Earnest?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Doe you intend to affront me, you had as good give me the lye.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: No, dear Sir, I beg your pardon for that, I believe you, But how came you to know it?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Her Sister Carolina told me so, and that she fell in love with you for reading a Copy of your own Verses: she sayes you read Heroick Verse with the best Grace of any man in England.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Before George she's in the right of that, but Sir—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: 'Slife ask no more questions, but to her and strike while the Irons hot: have you done you business Roger?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Most dextrously Sir.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Let's away—

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Love me? I am o'rejoy'd, I am sure I have lov'd her a great while.

div.stage: Enter Emilia, Woodcock following her singing.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Fa, la, la, la, &c.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Heav'n! this will distract me, what a vile noise he makes worse then the Creaking of a Barn door, or a Coach wheel ungreas'd.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: This is damn'd unlucky that he shou'd be here to hinder my design.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: What a pox makes him here, but I'le on in my bus'ness Madam, I'le speak you a Copy of Verses of my own that have a great deal of mettle and soul, and flame in'em.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: But I will not hear'em, Sir.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Alas poor fool he hopes to please her, but it won't do, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: What the devil can she mean by this, sure she can't be in Earnest: No, I have found it; Ay, ay, it must be so, she wou'd not have me speak before him, because she wou'd not have him take notice of her passion, but what care I—

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Prethee Ninny don't trouble the Lady with your Verses.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Well, well! Can't you let one alone—

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Fa, la, la, la, &c.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: What horrid Noise is this you make in my Ears? shall I never be free?

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Alas! poor Coxcomb he hopes to please her with his Voice: No, no, he may spare his pains— I am the man.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: What a pox ayles she? She's damnably out of humour what e'res the matter, I am sure Roger wou'd not deceive me of all men? what an ass am I, that I shou'd not find it, she's affraid my singing will incourage him to trouble her; or else she would not have him perceive her kindness—

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Sure all the world conspires against me this day?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Fa, la, la, la, &c.

div.stage: Wood. sings all the while Ninny repeats.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: reads My Love to that prodigious height does rise,
sp.l: 'Tis worthy of my heart and of your Eyes:
First of my heart, which being subdu'd by you,
Must for that Reason be both strong and true;
Then of your Eyes, which Conquerours must subdue:
And make 'em be both slaves and freemen too;
Your Eyes which do both dazle, and delight,
And are at once the Ioy, and grief of sight.
Love that is worthy of your face and fame
May be a glory, but can be no shame:
My heart by being o'recome does stronger prove,
Strength makes us yield unto your Eyes and Love.
In this my heart is strong, because 'tis weak,
This, though I hold my peace, my Love will speak,
Silence can do more then e're speech did doe,
For humble silence does doe more then wooe;
Under the Rose, which being the sweetest flower
Shews silence in us has then speech more power.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Why, what a damn'd Noise does he make; pox take me Madam, if one can be heard for him▪ Can't you let one alone with one's Verses trow.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Poor fellow! alas! he little thinks why I sing now?

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: If he thought how pleasant my rehearsing were to her, sure he wou'd not be so rude, but Mum for that.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: O Madam! your father's come to Town, and has brought a Country Gentleman to come a woing to you: he sent his man before hand to know if you were within, and one of the servants unluckily inform'd him before I cou'd see him: he sayes he's the most down-right plodding Gentleman the Countrey can afford.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: What will become of me? is there no mercy in store for me?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Is he coming— nay then— hem— They both take hold of Emilia, and hold her by force, and sing and repeat as fast agen as they did before.— hem.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: I'le make haste before he comes to hinder me.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: For Heav'ns sake let me goe.

sp.speaker: Wood. Ninn.
sp.p: Sing Repeat

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Oh, hold, hold, hold. I faint if you give not over.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: What a Devil does she mean by this, I am sure she loves me; but perhaps rather then indure the trouble of his Noise, she's willing to dispense with the pleasure of my Voice.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: A poise take this VVoodcock that he shou'd anger this Lady, as I hope to live he's a very impertinent fellow, for though she was troubled at him, I perceiv'd she was transported with me.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: It must be so, I must do ill that good may come on't: This Countrey-fellow will be the worst plague of all, since he has my fathers Authority to back him, I must be forc'd to subdue my own Nature, and flatter these Coxcombs to get rid of him, for they are so impudent they'l drive him from hence—

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: Madam, let me ask you in private, how did you like my song, speak boldly Madam, Ninny does not hear, Dear Heart?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: I must needs like it, Sir, or betray my own Judgement.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: Ah, Dear Roger! thou art a made man for ever. I am the man—

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: What's this I hear?

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: How did you like my Verses, Madam?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: So well Sir, that I hope you will let me hear 'em often. What am I reduc'd to?

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Oh Devil what's this?

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: How happy shall I be? the truth is I did perceive you were troubl'd at VVoodcocks senseless Songe, how we wou'd enjoy our selves if he were gone?

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Is it possible I shou'd be deceiv'd so much?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I'le tell thee Dear Heart, if thou bee'st troubled at Ninny's Rimes, upon my honour I'le beat the Rogue.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: This is she, Sir.

sp.speaker: Con. Gen.
sp.p: Your servant, Madam.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: ‛ Death she is a very Gossip, and Converses with all sort of fools, not only with patience, but with pleasure too, how civilly she entertains them? That I shou'd be such an Owl to think there could be a woman not impertinent, I have not patience to look upon her longer.—

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: It won't doe Ninny, her father little thinks she's ingag'd Dear Heart.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: No, no, her father little thinks she's ingag'd, aside. nor you neither, to whom— ha, ha, ha, it makes me laugh to think how this Countrey Gentleman will be bod'd Woodcock.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: He may go down Ninny like an Ass as he came, shee'l send him down with a flea in's ear take that from me.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: What a poise! he does not know she loves me! does he?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Poor fool! I pity him: ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: So do I, alack, alack.

sp.speaker: Cou. Gent.
sp.p: Madam, I am but just now come to Town, you see my Boots are dirty still, but I make bold as the saying is.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: More bold then welcome, I assure you Sir.

sp.speaker: Cou. Gent.
sp.p: Thank you good sweet Madam; this is the most obliging Gentlewoman that ever was—

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: By this he shewes the Impatience of his Love (Daughter.)

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Madam, I am a son of a Whore, if I have not the best song upon that subject, that ever you heard in your life.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Before George Madam, I'le repeat you Copy of Verses of my own ten times better then his song.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: You are an impudent Coxcomb to say so, Dear Heart, And ye lye, and I am satisfy'd.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Do I so, Madam, do but you judge.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: What can this mean? they are both mad.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.l: I am so impatient for to go to
my Dear,
That I run headlong without
wit or fear.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.l: What an impertinent fellow are you,
Woodcock cannot you let one alone.
So great the power of our love is now,
We can't persuade it reason for to allow.
Strange Miracle of Cytherea's force,
For to transform a man into a horse.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: My love is Cruel growne,
For to leave me all alone,
Thus for to sigh, and moan.
Ah woe is me!
Peace, Coxcomb, peace.
But I'le strive for to find
My love, though she's unkind,
So for to ease my mind.
Oh woe is me!
Hey ho, hey ho, my love,
Who is so Cruel as Jenny to me.

div.stage: They offer to sing and repeat agen.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Hold, hold, are you both mad, is the Devil in you, if he be, I shall have them will conjure him out of you. Come out you Coxcombs, or I'le drive you out.—

sp.speaker: Cou. Gent.
sp.p: These Gentlemen are as mad as March-Hares, Madam, as the saying is, but to our bus'ness, I had not the power as I was a saying, to keep from you longer, Lady, not so much as a pissing while, d'ye see! for Cat will to kind as the saying is.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, you complement, you are an absolute Countrey Courtier.

sp.speaker: Cou. Gent.
sp.p: Who I, alas not I, in sober sadness, we that live in the Countrey are right down d'e see, we call a spade a spade, as the saying is for our part.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: You doe well Sir, for hypocrisie is an abominable vice.

sp.speaker: Cou. Gent
sp.p: 'Tis indeed to be a Pharisy, and carry two faces in a hood, as the saying is.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Now I wish my to'ther two fools would come back and drive away this.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: I perceive you are very good at Proverbs, Sir don't you use to play at that sport with the Countrey Gentlewomen.

sp.speaker: Con. Gen.
sp.p: O yes, I am old dog at that, I am too hard for 'em all at it, d'e see. to Emilia. But Madam now we talk of the Countrey, how do you think you can like a Countrey life?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: O rarely! I can't chuse, to fill ones belly with Curds and Cream, and stewd Prunes, to eat Honey-comb, and Rashers of Bacon at poor neighbours houses, and Rise by five a clock in the Morning to look to my dayry.

sp.speaker: Co. Gent.
sp.p: O rare how we shall cotten together, as the saying is, I love a good huswife with all my heart, but Madam, I have a cast of Hawkes, and five couples of Spaniels too, oh Madam, if you saw my beloved Bitch Venus, you would be in love with her, shee's the best at a Retrieve of any Bitch in England d'e see.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Is he here? this is Heaven to me to see him after my late afflictions.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: To the Cou. Sir I have some bus'ness will engage me half an hour, pray will you avoid my sight in the mean time.

sp.speaker: Cou. Gent.
sp.p: I will forsooth, I'le go see my horses fed the while.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: This is a modester fool then the others I am troubl'd with, but if my father had been here I shou'd not so easily have got rid of him— What are you come agen?

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Ay, ay, too soon I am sure.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Are you not very foppish that you did not stay longer then?

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: This accusation becomes you well indeed.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Why not Sir?

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Alas, you are not impertinent, no, no, not you!

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: I am sure you are: what can this mean?

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: You were never pleas'd with Woodcocks damn'd voice yet, not Ninny's ridiculous Poetry, not you?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Not more, than your self.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: No, no, you were not pleas'd with them you did not praise 'em, nor entertain the other Two Fools with kindness, no not you?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: What a ridiculous thing 'twas of you not to tell me this in one word.
Oh Heaven! are they here!

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: How soon you can counterfeit the humour.

div.stage: Enter Sir Positive and Lady Vaine.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: You see, I am as good as my word Stanford.

sp.speaker: La. Va.
sp.p: You See, Madam, how ready I am to wait on your Ladiship.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Ay, to my cost I thank you.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: She thinks I am so easily bit as to take this for a satisfaction, but I am too old to be deceiv'd agen.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Now Madam to our bus'ness, if we don't put'em out of this humour, 'tis strange.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: However let's use our lawful Endeavours towards it.

sp.speaker: Wood. and Ninn.
sp.p: Sing Repeat.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: 'Slife Sir, I'le teach you to trouble this Lady with your pitiful Rimes.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: You teach me, nay, if you provoke me before Company you shall find me a Lion.—

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Have at y'e, Dear Heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: Hold Woodcock! why shou'd you disparage Poet Ninny, He's a man of admirable parts, and as cunning a fellow between you and I Stanford, I believe he's a Jesuite, but I am sure he's a jansenist.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: He a Jesuite, that understands neither Greek nor Latine.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p:
Now he talkes of that, Stanford, I'le tell thee what a Master I am of those Languages; I have found out in the Progress
of my Study, I must confess with some diligence, four and twenty Greek and Latine words for Black Puddens & Sausages.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Think to huff me? I cou'd show you a matter of 200 wounds I got when I was a Volunteer aboard the Cambridge, Dear Heart, wou'd make you swound to look upon 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: Cambridge, well that Cambridge is a good ship, and do you know, Stanford, that I understand a Ship better then any thing in the World.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Do you speak, Madam, you are pleas'd with this—

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Methinks you are as troublesome as he.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: You may talk of your Petts and your Deanes, Ile build a Ship with any of e'm for 10000. pound.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: VVhat will become of me, for if I shou'd goe, they wou'd follow me.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: This is extreamly well Painted.—

sp.speaker: Sir. Posit.
sp.p: Painted? VVhy? Do you understand Painting?

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Not I Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: I do; if you please leave that to me: 'Tis true, Michael Angelo, Titian, Raphael, Tintaret, and Iulio Romano, and Paulo Veronese were very pretty hopeful Men; but I wou'd you saw a Peice of mine, I shew'd you my Magdalen, Emilia, and I protest I drew that in half an houre.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: O! VVhat shall I do to get rid of all these Tormentors.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: I cannot but like this Woman, yet what ere's the matter; and yet I am sure she is impertinent.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: Let me see. H. H.— Oh Deare! Hans Holbin, here are Stroakes, here's Mastery; well, no man in England shall deceive me in Hans Holbins hand, take that from me.

sp.speaker: La. Vain.
sp.p: to Emilia. O' my Conscience, Madam, this Gentleman understands every thing in the World.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: In good earnest, Lovel, that's very pleasant Han's Holbin; why 'tis a new Sign for my Landlord, finish'd but yesterday, that cost him a Noble the Painting, done by a Fellow that Paints Posts, and Railes, one Humphrey Hobson, and he calls him Hans-Holbin.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Indeed Mr. Woodcock, fifty miles in a day was well run.

sp.speaker: Word.
sp.p: ‛ I faith was't Dear Heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: Run; why, Why will you pretend to running in my Company; you run, why I have run sixty miles in a day by a Ladies Coach, that I fell in Love withall in the streets, just as she was going out of Town, Stanford; and yet I vow to thee I was not breath'd at all that time.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: to Carol. There's Knight Errantry for you, Madam, let any of your Romances match me that now.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: to La. Vain. 'Tis true, Madam, Sir Positive and Poet Ninny are excellent men, and brave Bully-Rocks; But they must grant, that neither of e'm understand Mathematicks but my self.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: Mathematicks; why, Whos's that talkes of Mathematicks, let e'm alone, let e'm alone: Now you shall see Stanford.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: Why, 'twas I Dear Heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: I dear heart, quoth 'a; I don't think you understand the principles on't; 'o my Conscience you are scarce come so farr yet as the squaring of the Circle, or finding out the Longitude Mathematicks: Why this is the onely thing I value my selfe upon in the World Cozen Emilia.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Heav'n! deliver me.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Curse on e'm all.— Well, there must be something more in this Woman then I imagine.

sp.speaker: Ninny
sp.p: to Emilia. No man in England playes better upon the Cittern then I do, aske George my Barbor else, Madam, he's a great Judge.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: Cittern, Cittern! Who nam'd a Cittern there? Who was't▪ Who was't?

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Now am I affraid to speak to him, he does so snub one: 'Twas I and please you Sir Positive

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: You talke of a Cittern before me? when I invented the Instrument.

sp.speaker: Lov. VVoodcock.
sp.p: — Stand up to him in Mathematicks; To him.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: Say you so, well then, By the Lord Harry, Sir Positive, I do understand Mathematicks better then you; and I lye over against the Rose-Taverne in Coven-Garden, Deart Heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: I will justify with my Sword that you understand nothing at all on't— Draw.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: Nay, hold, hold, I have done Bully-Rock, if you be so angry; but it's a hard case you won't give a man leave to understand a little Mathematicks in your Company, Deare Heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: Pox on't, I have told thee often enough of this, thou wilt still be putting thy self forward to things thou do'st not understand.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: This Impudence is beyond all example, and there is no possibility of getting from e'm.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: I'le tell you one thing, Cozen, you cannot understand.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: I'le be hang'd then.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: You cannot Cheat at Dice.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: Ha, ha; Why you don't know me sure, you never heard of me.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Metaphysicks.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: Faith, well thought on, Lovel, prethee put me in mind of that presently, if I don't give you that account of Metaphisicks shall make you stare agen, cut my throat: But, as I hope to live, Stanford, 'tis a strange thing Carolina shou'd be so neer a Kin to me and not know me! False Dice, I have spent my time very well indeed, if any man out-does me in that; for your Goades, your High Fullams, and Low Fullams, your Cater Deuse Ace, and your Size Cater-Deuse, your sinke Trey Ace, your Barr Cater-Trey, your Barr-Sink-Deuse, your Barr-Sise-Ace, and all that, when I have study'd e'm these sixteen years— Cozen Emilia, you know this, don't you?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Oh horrid! What will become of me?

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Sure I was mistaken, for this must be a Woman of sence, I love her extreamly, I wou'd I did not.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: But what was that, Lovel, I desir'd you to put me in mind of?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Leger, De-Maine.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: Good, there 'tis now; I had thought I had kept that quality to my self of all things in the World: sure the Devil must help thee, Lovel, How coud'st thou come to know that I understood Leger-de-maine else? why, I'le perform all Tricks of Leger-de maine with any man in England, let him be what he will; For the Cups and Balls, Iack-in-a-Pulpit, St. Andrewes-Cross.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: Undoubtedly, Lovel, Cardinal Mazarine was a great States-man.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: States-man do you say? Cardinal Mazarine a States-man? well, I will say nothing of my self for that; no, I am no States-man: But, you may please to remember, who was bob'd at Ostend, ha, ha, What say you Stanford?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: O Heaven! Can you contrive no way of escaping?

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Let's e'ne try what we can do, for we had better be with one another then with these Fooles.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: Betwixt you and I, was the man that manag'd all that business against him.

sp.speaker: La. Vain.
sp.p: Good lack a day, Madam, this Gentleman has a bottomless understanding.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: He's a very rare man, and has great power and imagination.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: As any man in Europe, deare heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: This very thing has made me so famous all over Europe, that I may be at this instant Chiefe Minister of State in Russia, but the truth on't is, Stanford, I expect that neerer home.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Iacob Halls a most admirable Rope-Dancer, Mr. Woodcock.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: Honest Roger! How the Devil coud'st thou find me out in that, Iacob Hall has told thee, has he not? I thought he wou'd ha' kept that to himself; but I taught him, nay, I taught the Turke himself.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Hey, from a States-man to a Rope-Dancer, What a leap was there?

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: My Maid is excellent at Pastry.

sp.speaker: Sir. Posit.
sp.p: Ha, why there tis▪ now upon my Honour I understand this ten times better then any thing I have spoke off yet, Pastery, why, the Devil take me if I would not be content never to eate pye but of my own making as long as I live; I'le tell you, when I was but four years old, I had so rich a fancy, and made such extraordinary dirt pies, that the most eminent Cookes in all London, wou'd come and observe me, to steal from me.

sp.speaker: La. Vain.
sp.p: I beseech you, Madam Emilia, take notice of Sir Positive, he is a Prodigy of understanding.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: Ah Madam, 'tis your pleasure to say so; but 'twas this made me skilful in the art of Building, which is the onely Art I am proud of in the World; I'le tell you, Stanford, I have seventeen Modells of the City of London of my own making 〈◊〉 the worst of e'm makes London an other-guess London then 〈◊〉 like to be; but no man in England has those Modells of Houses that I have.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: This affliction is beyond all example; why the Devil do'st thou provoke him to this?

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Were it not a ridiculous thing of me not to please my self?

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: That's true; but, What will become of us in the mean time?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Heaven knows this door's lock'd, and there's no escaping at the other.

sp.speaker: Sir. Posit.
sp.p: I'le tell you, Madam, the other day a damn'd old Rat eate me up a Dining-roome and Withdrawing-Chamber worth Fifty pound.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: A Rat eate up a Dining-Roome and Withdrawing-Room, How cou'd that be?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: O fy, Sister, it's no matter how; why, Will you aske him?

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: Why, I make all my Modells of Houses in Paste; I vow to Gad I am asham'd to tell you how much it costs me in a year in Milk, Meale, Eggs and Butter.

sp.speaker: La. Vain.
sp.p: Dear Sir Positive, I think you understand more the● ever Solamon did.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: No, no, Madam, alass not I, I understand little, but I'le tell you, Madam, what was said of me the other day, by some great persons that shall be nameless.

sp.speaker: La. Vain.
sp.p: What was that, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: That I was a man of the most universal knowledge of any man in England; but without comparison the best Poet in Europe.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: — Now Lovel to your poast.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Navigation.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: Navigation d'ye talk of?

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: Geography.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: Geography d'ye talk of?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Astronomy.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: Astronomy d'ye talk of?

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: Palmestry.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Phisick.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Divinity.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Surgery.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Arithmetick.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Logick.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Cookery.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Magick.

div.stage: Lovel & Carolina speak so fast one after another, that Sir Positive turns himself first to one, then to another, & has not time to speak to them.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: Hold, hold, hold, hold!

Navigation, Geography, Astronomy, Palmestry, Phisick, Divinity, Surgery, Arithmetick, Logick, Cookery and Magick: I'le speak to every one of these in their order; if I don't understand e'm every one in perfection, nay, if I don't Fence, Dance, Ride, Sing, Fight a Duel, speak French, Command an Army, play on the Violin, Bag-pipe, Organ, Harp, Hoboy, Sackbut, and double Curtal, speak Spanish, Italian, Greek, Hebrew, Dutch, Welch and Irish, Dance a Jigg, throw the Barr, Swear, Drink, Swagger, VVhore, Quarrel, Cuffe, break Windowes, manage Affairs of State, Hunt, Hawke, Shoot, Angle, play at Catt, Stool-ball, Scotch-hopp and Trap-ball, Preach, Dispute, make Speeches.— Coughs. Prethee get me a glass of small beere, Roger.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Hell and Furies.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Oh, oh,—

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p:
Nay, hold, I have not told you halfe, if I don't do all these, and fifty times more, I am the greatest Owle, Pimp, Monkey, Jack-a-napes, Baboon, Rascal, O●fe, Ignoramus, Loggerhead, Cur-dog, Block-head, Buffoone, Jack-pudden, Tony, or what you will; spit upon me, kick me, cuff me, lugg me by
the eares, pull me by the Nose, tread upon me, and despise me more then the World now values me.—

div.stage: Ex. omnes, and he goes out talking as fast as he can.

div.head: ACT. V.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: IF you be my Friend, as you profess to be, you will not deny me this.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I am your Friend, and would not have you perplex your self with what you see there's no end of; Can this frowardness relieve you?

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Good sir, none of your Grave advice, I am resolv'd to relieve my selfe, by abandoning all conversation.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: How can you brook Emilia's company?

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Pish! she's not altogether so troublesome: aske me no more Questions.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Hah! Does he like her? Thus farr my Designe thrives: Well! I'le keep e'm from you a while: but the Hounds are so eager, they'l never endure pole-hunting Long.—

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: You hear, Madam, we are not like to be long free from these inhumane persecutors.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Why will you call e'm so? you know I am pleas'd with e'm: They are my Recreation as you were pleas'd to say.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: No, no; you have convinc'd me of the Contrary: but, How can you blame me for so easie a Mistake?

sp.speaker: Emili.
sp.p: You are a very fit Man to despise impertinent people: you are!

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: 'Till be very wisely done to stand muttering here, till the Fooles in the next Room-break-in upon you.

sp.speaker: Emili.
sp.p: Perhaps as wisely done, as to trust my selfe with you, as you have behav'd your self.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: If you have no more sence then to stay longer: I shall be assur'd of what I was but jealous of before.

sp.speaker: Emili.
sp.p: What would your wisdome have me do now?

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: The VVorst of them would not have ask'd such a Question: who but you would be in doubt, or would not fly as a Thiefe does from a Hue and Cry.

sp.speaker: Emili.
sp.p: There's no hope of escaping.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Now will you in despair of avoiding them, stay here, and keep e'm company.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: 'Twere vaine presumption to hope for Liberty by Miracle; they will no more lose us, then an Attorny will a young Squire that's newly waded into Law; who will be sure never to leave him till he has brought him out of his depth.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: By this rule you shou'd not resist a Man that comes to Ravish you, because he's like to be too strong for you; but if you did not use the meanes, your honesty would be no more admir'd is that, then your Wisdome in this.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Aside. This is a most admirable person.— Where should I go?

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: I would run into a fire to be quitt of e'm.

sp.speaker: Emil.
