sp.p: Well! I am content to go along with you, not for your sake, but my own.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Perhaps my inclinations are not much unlike yours.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: O Stanford, I can no longer keep them from you, 'tis as easie to stop a Spring-Tide.

div.stage: Enter Lovel. Carol. Sir Pos. Nin. Wood. La. Va.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Now, Whose fault was this? a Curse upon your delaying, now 'tis too late to fly.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: Do'st talke of flying, Iack; I'le teach thee to do that with the greatest ease in the World: 'tis true, I heard of a Coxcomb that broke his neck with the Experiment, but if I had been by him, I wou'd have taught him to have flown with the best Goss-Hawke in the World.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: O! Impudence!

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: And for my own part for one flight or so, for I will not straine my self for any mans pleasure; I do't but for my Recreation: I am not mercenary. I will fly at a Herne with the rest Jer-Faulcon that ever flew; that's faire.

sp.speaker: La. Vain.
sp.p: O very Fair! as can be, by all means Sir learn of him hee'l do't.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: Do't Madam, I think so: I tell you all Elements are alike to me, I could live in any one of 'em as well as the Earth: 'Tis nothing but a sordid Earthy Nature in us makes us love the Earth better then any other Element.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: I see it is in vain to torment our selves without endeavouring our Liberty.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: That's cunningly found out.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Sir, if you can find a way to be rid of Sir Positive, and my Lady Vaine, I'le tell you how to quit your selves of the other.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: We may set 'em one upon another, and by that we may either get rid or (at least) be a little reveng'd of 'em.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: That may make some amends for your last neglect.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Now they are settl'd in their bus'ness, I'le leave 'em and go to my Tyrewoman in Coven-Garden, who has some Excellent new Patterns of Lace for me, will you please to Squire me along.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I hope you have no design upon me: are your Intentions honourable?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Yes indeed are they, I intend no rape upon you.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Nor any other unlawful way of love.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Leave fooling, and let's away— Ex. Lov. Car.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: to Lady Vain. P'shaw! I could live in the water so well: that o' my Conscience I am Amphibious, I could catch fi●● as well as any Cormorant or Otter, ●●y I can live so long under-water, that (but that I have greater designs on foot here) I would go into the West Indies to dive for Sponges and Corals, and if in one year I were not the richest man that ever went thither I wou'd be hang'd Iack Stanford when I swom over agen.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: 'Sdeath I would you were under water one half hour in the mean time.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p:
Faith I would I were Iack, thou wou'dst admire to see
what pleasure I take in lying under Water an hour or two, especially if the Water be warm!

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Yes, yes, and you can eat fire too? can't yee?

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: P'shaw! you admire a man that eats fire among you, one that has a deprav'd pallate, and is not able to taste an Ash from an Oak-Coal, which I can distinguish as well as I can a pickl'd Herring from a Muscle.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Eate fire it is Impossible?

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: You are a Fopp, I pity your ignorance, eat fire? Why I'le eate Fire and Brimstone with the Devil himself man, what dost talk of that?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: to Emilia. I warrant you, Dear Heart, I'le do't, and yet I am plaguelly affraid of Sir Positive.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: What am I forc'd to? Master Ninny, you have often profest some kindness to me.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: And Madam may I never make Couplet agen if I don't love you better then I do Musick or Poetry.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: And understand me as little—
I shall soon make trial of you.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: And before George if I do not serve you!—

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Then be sure the next thing Sir Positive pretends to: Contradict him in, and be as Positive as he is, and by this perhaps, you may deserve my kindness.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: But suppose, Madam, he should draw upon me, and do me a Mischief.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Master Stanford and his man will bail you from that.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: In confidence of this I shall be glad to serve you.

sp.speaker: La. Vain.
sp.p: I wonder, dear Sir, a man of your incomparable Ability's shou'd want preferment.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: Modesty! modesty! we that are modest men get nothing in this age.

sp.speaker: Lady Vain.
sp.p: Perhaps the World does not know of these things!

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: Not know! why I was never in Company with any man in my life; but I told him all.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: And no man ever believ'd you, Dear Heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: As I hope to breath, Iack this fellow's mad.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p:
Ne're tell me, Dear Heart, I know you understand nothing
of all you have pretended to in comparison of me, Dear Heart.

sp.speaker: Sir. Pos.
sp.p: Is not this very pleasant, Madam, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Nay, nay, never laugh for the matter, and think to bear up against all the World, do you think I don't think my self a better Poet then you.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: And I a better Musitian;

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: You Impudent Baboons!

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Let him alone, let him alone Woodcock.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Ay, ay, alas I laugh at him: ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: Madam, the party has stay'd for you a good while at the setting Dog and Partridge.

sp.speaker: La. Va.
sp.p: Come, while they dispute, let's go—

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Nay, Madam, if you don't stay to prevent Mischief, I have done: for I find I begin to grow furious, and dare not trust my own temper.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: Have you the Impudence to say you are a better Poet, and you a better Musitian than I am?

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Ay, ay, and not onely so, but a better Divine, Astrologer, Mathematician, Geographer, Seaman—

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: A better Physician, Lawyer, States-man, Almanack-maker.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Ay, and what shall break your heart, a better Trap-ball-player too, take notice of that—

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: In one word, I understand every thing that is or is not to be understood better then you doe: take that from me.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: And let me tell you, Sir Positive, 'tis a very confident thing in you to pretend to understand any thing as well as I do.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: O Impudence!

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: You understand! how should you come by understanding. Where had you your Knowledge, Dear Heart? P'shaw.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: What will this age come to?

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p:
You Insolence makes me blush, as I hope to breath, for
such an empty fellow to talk of wit or sence; p'shaw, prethee hold thy Tongue.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: I am amaz'd!

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I tell thee, dear Soul, I love thee so well, I would not have thee pretend to these things thou dost not understand.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Especially before such men as we that do understand.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: I can hold no longer, ye eternal Dogs, ye Currs, ye Ignorant Whelps: I'le sacrifice ye, let me go: if there be no more sons of Whores in England, I'le murder 'em.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Bear up to him, I'le prevent all Injuries.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Nay then Sir; never fret and fume for the matter: look you Sir, pray what can you do better then I?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Or I either: let's hear't, Dear Heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: Hear it you Rascals, I'le rout an Army with my single valour: I'le burn a whole fleet at three Leagues distance; I'le make ship● go all over the world without sayles: I'le plow up rocks steep as the Alps in dust, and lave the Tyrrhene Waters into Clouds (as my friend Cateline sayes.)

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: P'shaw! you! I'le pluck bright honour from the pale fac'd Moon (as my friend Hot-spur sayes) what do you talk of that?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Certainly, he's distracted! this is some revenge.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: This single head of mine shall be the balance of Christendom: and by the strength of this I'le undermine all Common wealths, destroy all Monarchies, and write Heroick Playes: ye dogs let me see either of you do that.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: This is raving madness.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Wou'd I were well ●id of him, I tremble every joynt of me.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: With this right hand I'le pluck up Kingdoms by the roots, depopulate whole Nations, burn Cities, murder Matrons, and ravish sucking Infants, your Currs can you do this?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: But Sir in the midst of your fury my Lady Vaine is gone away with a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: Ah dear Roger which way did she go? show me quickly I'le bring her back and she shall see me take satisfaction of these Rascals.—

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I'm glad you are gone, Sir, my heart was at my mouth, did I not do the business rarely, my pretty Rogue? How canst thou reward me for this? hah?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Unfortunate Woman! what am I reduc'd to? if you will go immediately to Oxford Kates, and stay for me in the great Room there, I will not fail to come to you in a little time. And let you know how sensible I am of this favour; go, go instantly and make no words on't.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I fly, Madam, O dear Roger: I have catch'd her, O Rogue! I'le provide a parson immediately: dear son of Whore let me kiss thee.—

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: I shall have a better opinion of her Wit then ever I had, if she gets rid of this brace of Iack-Puddens.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Ay Madam, you see what danger I have undergone: I am onely unhappy I have lost no bloud in the service: for as a Noble Author sayes,— It would have been to me both loss and gain. But shall I hope for any favour from you.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Let not Stanford perceive any thing; go and stay for me at Oxford Kates in the great Roome, and there we may freely speak our Minds.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: And will you not fail to come?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: No, no, but what ever happens remove not till I come to you: away, away, we are observ'd.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: O admirable Fortune! sure I was born with a Caul on my Head, and Wrapt in my Mothers Smock, the Ladies do so love me.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: I would these Two fools were oblig'd to stay there till I came to 'em.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Now I hope you will take Warning, and stay here no longer, where they may find you out, unless you take pleasure in 'em.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Where can I find a place of safe retreat?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: I have a sister lives in Coven-garden a Tyre-woman, where at this time of night you may be private: if you please command the house.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Make haste then! O Heav'n is he return'd?

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: Pox on't I can't find my Mistress; where are these Rogues?

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: My Lady Vaine is return'd, and Ninny and Woodcock are with her in the next room.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: Say you so? I'le in and first make the Puppy's recant their errours, and then murder 'em in presence of my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: So! you are fast.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Come away, away!

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: within. Stanford open the door, are you mad? hey Stanford! Cozen Emilia! open the door.

sp.speaker: La. Vain.
sp.p: What is the house empty?— 'Twas an unlucky thing That the Gentlemen should go before we came.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: That may thank Sir Positive; would he were far enough for me for keeping your Ladiship so long.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: Stanford: Emilia! open the door! there! help, help! help.

sp.speaker: La. Va.
sp.p: That's his voyce! what can be the matter? the Key is in the door, I'le in and see—

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: O Madam! your humble servant! If I don't murder Stanford may I never have any share in your Ladiships favour.

sp.speaker: La. Va
sp.p: Did he lock you in?

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, for which with this blade that is inur'd to slaughter, will I slice him into Attoms.

sp.speaker: La. Va.
sp.p: No sweet Sir Positive restrain your passion, such a fellow 〈◊〉 he deserves to be toss'd in a blanket.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: No, no, never talk of that Madam! Such a Revenge is below me, but I have a Pen that will bite and I'le do it vigorously. And yet the Rogue has done me a kindness: for if he had not lock'd me up, I had miss'd of your Ladiship.

sp.speaker: La. Va.
sp.p: Sir, upon my honour, I intended not to have stay'd from you!

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: But Madam, the loss of you has put me into that fright that I desire to make sure of you.

sp.speaker: La. Va.
sp.p: As how, good Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir. Posit.
sp.p: To marry you this Night!

sp.speaker: La. Va.
sp.p: That's short Warning.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: But Madam, I have had your promise these three days And that's long enough to expect performance.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: Madam! e'en take him at his Word.

sp.speaker: La. Va.
sp.p: But how shall I answer that to my friend in the Countrey?

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: Ne're trouble your self for that Madam, 'tis fashionable to have a servant as well as a husband, and besides the pleasure of a Gallant, there will be another, which is no small one to some women, of deceiving your husband.

sp.speaker: La. Va.
sp.p: Thou art in the right Wench: besides the failing of this assignation has set me so a Gogg I would very unwillingly lye alone to night.

sp.speaker: Sir. Pos.
sp.p: Come Madam, I see you are consulting: Ile send for a Parson shall soon finish the debate.

sp.speaker: La. Va.
sp.p: Well Sir! Your Intentions are so honorable, I submit to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: O intollerable happiness: Let's dispatch it immediately in this house.

sp.speaker: La. Va.
sp.p: No Sir! I'le carry you to a more private place.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: Come Madam, I'le wait on you.—

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Now I have dispatch'd this important bus'ness of woman-kind, which is making themselves fine, we may return

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: To the place from whence we came, and from thence to the place of Execution; if you please: I'le have a Levite ready.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: No Sir, I know you are too true a Son of the Church to venture that after the Canonical hour.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I am not so formal to observe a Method in any thing besides Marriage, being at best unseasonable, can never be less then now.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: To speak gravely; let us first take the advice of our pillows: since sleep being a great settler of the brain may be an Enemy to Marriage, for one wou'd think that few in their right Wits wou'd undertake so unseasonable an action: as you call it.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Must people then be tam'd into Marriage? as they man Hawks with watching.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What's here? my Sister with Stanford?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: How unlucky is this, my Sister and an idle fellow with her.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Ne're trouble your self if your Sister be not a Fopp: He's none I'le assure you.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: You are a very Competent Judge indeed.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: How now Sister can you with all your gravity steal away by night with a Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Come Stanford: there's Love betwixt you for nothing else can make men and women so shame fac'd as to seek out private places.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Come Sister if it be so: ne're mince the matter, 'tis the way of all flesh.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: And we are so far onward on that way that if you don't make haste you will scarce overtake us.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Come confess Emilia what brought you hither?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: I came to fly from Impertinence, and I have found it here.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: That will not bring you off Sister: for if you did not like this Gentleman very well, you wou'd fly from him assoon as any man.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: For my part I onely came to defend her from Assaults at this time o' night.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p:
If you had not an Extraordinary value for her you
would not play the Knight-Errant to my Knowledge; Is not this dissimulation of yours very ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: I must needs confess I never saw any VVoman I dislik'd less.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: And, What say you Sister of this Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: To give the Devil his due, I have met with less affliction from him then from other men.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: Nay, then in good earnest it must be a match.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: That's wisely propos'd of you to me, that am immediately leaving the World.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: to Emil. Pox on her! how she pleases me.— Aside. Why, VVho intends to stay behind?

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: If you neglect this opportunity, Sister, you'l ne're be so well match'd agen.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: 'Twill not be so pleasant to go alone as you imagine.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: No, no, take hands and march along I say.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: That wou'd be much to the advantage of my honour.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I'le send for one shall satisfie that scruple, Madam.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: The remedy is almost as bad as the Disease.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Perhaps if you consider, it 'twill be your VVisest● course.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: No doubt I shou'd have an admirable Companion of you, as you think.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: I find you have so great a passion for the Country Gentleman my Father has provided for you, you will never be perswaded to be false to him.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: He will be the greatest plague of all: What shall I do to be rid of him?

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: There is but one way Sister; E'ne dispose of your self to that honest Gentleman to have and to hold.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: 'Twill be very discreetly done, not to quit your self of this Country Fellow, and the rest of your Fooles, now it is in your power.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: 'Faith, Madam, be perswaded and joyn hands.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: The truth is, I think we cannot do better then to leave the World together: 'twill be very uncomfortable wandring in desarts for you alone.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: If I shou'd be so mad as to Joyn hands with you, 'twould not be so much an Argument of Kindness to you, as Love to my self; since at best I am forc'd to chuse the least of two great Evils, either to be quite alone, or to have ill Company.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: This will end in Marriage I see.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: O no! I dare not think of that, if he shou'd grow troublesome, then 'twou'd be out of my power to cast him off.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Why there's no necessity we should be such Puppies as the rest of Men and Wives are, if we fall out, to live together, and quarrel on.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: The Conditions of VVedlock are the same to all.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: VVhatsoever the Publick Conditions are, our private ones shall be, if either growes a Fopp, the other shall have liberty to part.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: I must confess that's reasonable.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Away Roger, and fetch a Canonical Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: I will Sir.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, you have taken great paines, Was't for your self or me you did it?

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: You have a very civil opinion of your self I see.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: O Sir! yonder's Sir Positive and my Lady Vaine just alighted at the Door, with the man you sent for.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: O undone! ruin'd for ever!

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Slife you Rascal, did not you tell me I might be private here?

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Pray Sir do not fret, but make your escape out at the back doore.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Away, away! quickly for Heavens sake!

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Come, Madam! let's follow e'm.—

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Will you never leave ones roome a little; I tell you I am busie.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: So am I, and 'tis my roome deare heart, let me tell you that.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Before George, Woodcock, 'tis very Impertinent to trouble one thus.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: So 'tis, Ninny, I wonder you'l do't; for my part, a man that had the least Soul of Poetry in him, would scorne to do this.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: What! Do you say I have not a Soul of Poetry in me? I don't love to commend my self Woodcock; but, now I am forc't to't: I must tell you, I have six times as much power in me, as you have.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: You lye dear heart!

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Why, you lie then, to tell me that I lye, so you doe.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: You are a Son of a Whore, dear heart, to tell me I lye.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: You are a Son of a VVhore as well as my selfe, to tell me so, and you go to that.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I, I, you may say your pleasure; but have a care Bully-Rock, for if you give me the least affront, I'le break your Pate, take that from me.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: I'le take it from no man: if you doe; I'le break yours agen man, for all you are so briefe: 'Slife, one shan't speak to you one of these dayes, you are grown so purdy.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Well! well! Dear Heart!

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: VVell well too! and you go to that: if you be so fierce: But, I'de faine know what occasion there is for you and I to quarrel now?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Ay, what indeed dear heart; Therefore, prethee Dear Soul Kiss me, Dear Rogue, if thou lov'st me, go out of my Roome.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: No, good sweet Woodcock now, go thee, I'le do as much for thee another time, as I hope to Live.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Dear Cutt I love thee; but prethee excuse me, I have a Mistress to meet in this very Roome; Therefore dear pretty Ninzy leave me.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Cods my Life kins to see the luck on't: may I never versify agen if I am not here upon the same occasion: I'le give thee five Guynny's if thou'lt leave me: I shall spare e'm well enough when I have got her.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I'de have you know, Ninny, I scorn your Guinny's, alass, poor Foole, he little thinks I shall be in a better Condition to spare fifty then he can five: VVhy then, in short, let me tell you I am to be marry'd within this halfe hour, in this very Roome, dear heart.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: This is prodigious! may I never have Play take agen if I am not to be marry'd here within this halfe hour, and to a very great Fortune too.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: So is mine, Bully-Rock!

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Dear VVoodcock, let's reconcile this business here; I have two Dice, he that throws most stayes: then am I sure to be too hard for him that way, for I can nap a Six a-yard.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: No, not I: by the Lord Harry, I'le not trust a business of that Concernment to Fortune.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Nay, then Sir, I will keep my Roome, I was first in't.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: By that rule you shou'd go first out.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: 'Tis not you can turn me out.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Say you so: I'le try that!

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: At your own peril!

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: Can't you stand a little? Why do you go back so dear heart?

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Let me alone, I know what I do in going back, I have the Law on my side, and if I kill you, it will be found se defendendo.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Have you murd'rous Intentions dear heart? If you do kill me, I will declare upon my Death-bed, That you had Malice in your heart, dear heart.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Who I? as I hope to be sav'd I scorn your Words: I Malice; do your worst: I am better known then so: I am not so outragious: pray hear me a Word: You know we Authors and Ingenious Men have a great many Enemies.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: We have so.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: At this rate we may kill one another: and a Pox on e'm they'd be glad on't; and for my part I wou'd not dye to please any of e'm.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: Nor I neither; therefore prethee leave me my Roome, to prevent danger.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: I am not so base: but, if you will, let us lay down these dangerous Engines of Blood, and Contend a safer way, by the way of Cuffe and Kick.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: Ay, ay, with all my heart; what a Pox care I: come, come, you shall see I dare do any thing, since you are resolv'd to try me.

div.stage: Enter two Servants, and part e'm, & Ex.
Enter Stanford, Lovel, Carol, Emilia, Roger.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Here we are in as much danger as ever: Could any thing be so foppish as returning to the place from whence we fled.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: 'Tis a sweet time of night to go upon the Ramble.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: We are safe enough from any body but my Father; and we cannot be troubled with him long: 'tis his hour of going to Bed.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: How shall we dispose of the Country Fellow, if he should return.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Let me alone; I'le find a Trick for him: I liv'd in the same Town with him, and know him to be a down-right credulous man, that will swallow any thing.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Now see what you have brought your self to?

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Come Daughter, What think you of my choice of a Husband, He's extreme rich; and, Is he not a very accomplish'd Gentleman, hah?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: There's a Fellow indeed, why he has not Soul enough for a Cock-Chicken.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: You are a foolish froward Girle thus to despise your happiness; I'le tell you, either resolve to Marry him to morrow morning—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Heark you Sir! if you will take my advice, be not so hasty: you know young Ladies are alwayes Coy, and out of their little knowledge of the World, are apt to refuse that which may prove their greatest happiness.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: What would you have me do with one that is so obstinate?

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: If you please, take some milder way: let us withdraw, and wee'l all help to perswade her: you know it is not proper to be done before him.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: I'le be rul'd in this: but if perswasions will not do, force shall.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: Be sure you seeme pliant to his Commands, it may advance our designe.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Sir, wee'l wait on you agen presently.

div.stage: Ex. all but Country G. and Roger.

sp.speaker: Coun. Gen.
sp.p: Your Servant Sir!— honest Roger in sober sadness I am glad to see you well; I had almost forgot you.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: And, How does your sweet Sister Madam Dorothy?

sp.speaker: Coun. Gent.
sp.p: O brave and lusty, as sound as a Roach, as they say.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: I heard your Worship was Knighted.

sp.speaker: Count. Gent.
sp.p: No▪ not I Roger: I am not ambitious of that: As that excellent Proverb sayes; Honour will buy no Beife.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Now we are alone, Sir, I am oblig'd to tell you; I am sorry to▪ see one, whom I so much honour'd, so ill us'd.

sp.speaker: Count. Gent.
sp.p: Pish! its no matter man! I care not for Knighthood one pin of my slieve, as the saying is.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Sir, I mean something concernes your Worship nearer.

sp.speaker: Count. Gent.
sp.p: Nearer! What can that be?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: I must beg your Pardon for that; I may be ruin'd for my Endeavours to serve you.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: VVhat, VVould any of your Town-Gallants bob me of my Mistress?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: That were too good newes for you to be true?

sp.speaker: Count. Gent.
sp.p: Thank you for nothing: Is this the honour you have for me, to wish me the loss of a Mistress worth 10000. l. d'ye see; udds nigs that's a good one indeed.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: 10000. l. Ha, ha, ha; would she had it for her own sake and yours too?

sp.speaker: Count. Gent.
sp.p: Faith are you there with your Bears? nay then I have brought my Hoggs to a fair Market.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: If she had had one of those thousands my Master would have Marry'd her long e're this; Sir, I have alwayes honour'd you, and could not in Conscience but tell you this, and now it is in your power to ruine me.

sp.speaker: Count. Gent.
sp.p: Nay, I'le be as silent as a Dormous, but is it possible?—

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Nay, do not believe me if you please; but I have discharg'd my duty: and, if you Marry her, the Inconvenience will be yours, not mine: Besides, if she had that Fortune you speak of, which she has as much as I have; What good would it do you in the end? She'l ner be perswaded to live in the Country, you must keep her in Town, with her Coach and six Horses, Pages and Lacquies: and she must visit the Playes, the Park, and the Mulberry-Garden.

sp.speaker: Count. Gent.
sp.p: O Lamen-table! this were the way to get a pair of Hornes bigger then the Staggs head in My-Hall has: but, if I were Marry'd to her, I'd get her into the Country as sure as a Gun.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: If you shou'd, you'd have every week this Earle, that Lord; this Knight, and that Gentleman of her kindred come to take the fresh Aire; and to Hunt and Hawke with you in time of year.

sp.speaker: Count. Gent.
sp.p: Why they wou'd eate me out of House and Home, as the saying is.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: They would despise your Beife and Mutton: you must keep a Couple of French-Cookes; and eate nothing but Potages, Fricasces, and Ragusts, your Champinions, Coxcombes and Pallats, your Andoilles, your Langue de porcean, your Bisks and your Olio's.

sp.speaker: Count. Gent.
sp.p: What are all these, several sorts of Sweet-Meats.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: O no Sir! these must be your constant food, and every Dish will cost you a Piece; and, Will this be done with a small Portion of a Thousand Pound.

sp.speaker: Count. Gent.
sp.p: I shou'd soon bring a Noble to Nine-pence then as they say.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Then you must have your Quailes, Ruffs, Gnatts, Godwitts, Plover, Dotrills, Wheat-Eare, Cock of the Wood, and a hundred sorts of Fowles: besides, they would scorn your Ale and Sider, and March-Beer: you must have your Sellar full of Champaign, Chablee, Burgundy, and Remedy Wines; But Mum Sir, if you love me.

div.stage: Enter Father, Stanf. Emil. Carol. Lov.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Come, Sir, I have brought my Daughter to be obedient to my Commands, and I would have you prepare to be Marry'd to morrow morning,

sp.speaker: Count. Gent.
sp.p: I shall faile you d'ye see.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: What is't you say?

sp.speaker: Count. Gent.
sp.p: I shan't be so civil, as the saying is.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: This is madness.

sp.speaker: Count. Gent.
sp.p: No Sir, no; There's no catching old Birds with Chaffe, Fare-you-well.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: D'hear Sir!

sp.speaker: Count. Gent.
sp.p: No, Sir, fare ye well— I am no Bubble, as they say.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: I am amaz'd! I'le after him; and inquire into the business, I must not lose this Son-in-Law.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: The Rogue has done it dexterously.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Come Sir, here's a Parson in the next Roome, dispatch, while the old Gentleman's out of the House.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: 'Slife, Woodcock's here! I'le cut his Throat.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Pray none of your Hectoring here, to Alarm the House.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: How now, Dear Heart! Why did not you come to me as you promis'd.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: For Heavens sake go up into the Room two pair of Stairs, and I'le steal from hence, and give you an Account: make haste.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Come let's in before we be interrupted agen.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Hi'st Madam; before George 'twas unkindly done, not to remember your assignation just now.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: You'l spoil all: I could not get loose; run into the garden there's a back door: I'le come to you immediately, make haste, we are observ'd.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: O ho! this is something.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: This woman has a soul.—

sp.speaker: Huff.
sp.p: I have pursu'd him into this house, that has abus'd me so basely behind my back, and by this Whiniard, and by the spirit of Gun-powder: I'le sacrifice him to my fury: Come out you son of a Whore.

div.stage: Enter Stanford, and the rest after him, Stanford presses upon Huffe, and he falls.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: That this Puppy shou'd provoke me to draw upon him, that is so drunk he cannot stand.

sp.speaker: Huff.
sp.p: That's a mistake, not so drunk yet, but if I had stood soberly to't, I should have been run through the Lungs before this.

div.stage: Enter Sir Positive and Lady Vaine.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Is there no end of our affliction?

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: Dear Cozen and Iack Stanford, give me Joy, I am marry'd to a Lady that is the greatest Pattern of Wit: and the greatest Example of Vertue that this age hath produc'd, and for her face look upon't, took upon it I say! she's a beauty take that from me, what say you Stanford?

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Yes, yes, she's cursedly hansome.

sp.speaker: La. Va.
sp.p: If my glass does not flatter me: you are not deceiv'd in your Judgment, dear Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: Here I have brought Fiddles to rejoyce with you Iack and Cousin, since I know you love mirth as well as I do.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I had waited for thee my dear Miss if this unexpected Musick had not brought me hither.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: How now? what Fiddles are these?

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: You dogs are you here? now Madam you shall see how I'le chastise these fellows that wou'd be Wits.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Hold dear Rogue! why should'st thou be angry? upon my honour I did but droll with thee, for by the Lord Harry I take thee to be one of the pillars of the Nation Dear Heart?

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: O' do you so?

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Dear Sir Positive, I beg your pardon a thousand times, For my part I believe there never was a man of that prodigious understanding that you have.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: Do you so? I knew it was impossible they shou'd be in Earnest, but do you hear? have a Care of being Positive another time, a man wou'd think you might learn more Modesty of me.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Come Dear Heart, art thou here: prethee kiss me, and let's be friends for all our late Cuffing: what need we care for a douce or two of the Chops Bully Rock.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Nay for my part I value it as little as you do, and you go to that.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: What Ryots this in my house? at this time o' night?

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: Riot! do you understand what a Riot is in Law: I'le tell you: for no man in this Nation has committed more then I have.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Tell me not of Law Sir? what mean these Fiddles I say at this time o' night?

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: Unckle they are mine: I am marry'd to this Lady, and resolve to be merry in your house before we go to Bed.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Is that it? give you Joy, your Cozin Emilia and this Gentleman will not be long after ye.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: Sir, you are mistaken, your daughter has dispos'd her self in another place.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: How the devil did he know that Ninny?

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: He little thinks where she has bestow'd her self, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: No, no, nor thee neither, dear Rogue, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Well! honest VVoodcock, I think I may trust thee, thou art my Friend; I am the man she has made choice of, and thou shalt be my Bride man.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, poor whelp! how he will find himself bobb'd immediately: that this Coxcomb should not find all this while that I am the man.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: It cannot be what without my Knowledge or Consent?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Ay, ay, she's dispos'd on; Dear Heart.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Ay, Ay, she's dispos'd on.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: To whom?

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.p: To me.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: To me.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: To me.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: How now to all three?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Sir, she has taken Master Stanford, and I Master Lovell as sure as a Parson can make us.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: What do I hear?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Sir, I beseech you be not offended, their Births and Fortunes are not unequal to ours, and if they were, 'twere too late for it to be redrest.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Is this true?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Yes Sir, perhaps too true.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Am I fool'd after all this? well I say no more, Dear Hearts.

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Well let the Nation sink or swim an'it will for me: henceforward instead of Heroick Verse, hereafter I will shew all my power, and soul and flame, and mettle in Lampoon, I durst have sworn she had lov'd me.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Well! Heaven bless you together since you have don't.

sp.speaker: Co. Gen.
sp.p: So Sir, I see my Cakes dough, as they say; but I hope you'l pay the Charges of my Journey d'ye see.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: Well Cozins I am glad of your good Fortunes, and for my own part, if I understand any thing in the world I am happy in this Lady.

sp.speaker: La. Vain.
sp.p: Sir! you are pleas'd to Complement.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Sir Positive here's a Letter was left for you, it comes out of the Countrey.

sp.speaker: Sir Posit.
sp.p: reads SIr Positive I am inform'd, but know not how to believe it, that you intend to marry one that calls her self my Lady Vaine: The respect▪ I have for your family urges me to tell you she is a Counterfeit Lady, and is at present my Mistress, by whom I have had one child, and I believe she's half gone of another, all the Fortune she has is what I allow her.
sp.l: I have seen enough, how am I perplex'd? read Lovell.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Come Master Woodcock! and Master Ninny notwithstanding you are displeas'd let's have your Company a little longer.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Nay for my part, Dear Heart, I do not care what becomes of me?

sp.speaker: Ninn.
sp.p: Nor I neither as little as any man.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Don't betray your self to the Company.

sp.speaker: Sir Pos.
sp.p: Well! this is the first thing in the World that I have met with which I did not understand: but I am resolv'd, I'le not acknowledge that: Master Lovell I knew well enough what I did when I marry'd her, He's a wise man that marry's a harlot, he's on the surest side, who butan Ass would marry at uncertainty.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: What will not a Positive Coxcomb defend?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Since we are all agreed: in stead of a grand Dance according to the laudable Custome of Weddings, I have found out a little Comical Gentleman to entertain you with.

div.stage: Enter a boy in the habit of Pugenello, and traverses the Stage, takes his Chair, and sits down, then Dances a Iigg.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: No Wedding day was ever so troublesome as this has been to me.

sp.speaker: Stanf.
sp.l: Make haste and quit the Trouble.
Now to some distant desart let's repair:
And there put off all our unhappy Care,
There certainly that freedom we must find,
Which is deny'd to us among Mankind.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: PHysitians tell us, that in every age
Some one particular Disease does rage,
The Scurvy once, and what you call the Gout,
But Heaven be prais'd their Reign is almost out;
Yet a worse malady then both is bred,
For Poetry now reigneth in their stead:
The Itch of writing Playes, the more's the pity,
At once has seis'd the Town, the Court, and City.
Amongst the rest the Poet of this day▪
By meer infection has produc'd a Play.
Once his hot fit was strong when he was bold
To write, but while you judge hee's in the Cold,
Yet pray consider, few of you but may
Be given up so farre to write a Play:
If not for his, for your own sakes be kinde,
And give that mercy which you hope to finde.
